</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-below" style="background:#efefef;">
<a class="image" href="/wiki/File:A_coloured_voting_box.svg"><img alt="icon" class="noviewer thumbborder" data-file-height="160" data-file-width="160" decoding="async" height="16" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/01/A_coloured_voting_box.svg/16px-A_coloured_voting_box.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/01/A_coloured_voting_box.svg/24px-A_coloured_voting_box.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/01/A_coloured_voting_box.svg/32px-A_coloured_voting_box.svg.png 2x" width="16"/></a> <a href="/wiki/Portal:Politics" title="Portal:Politics">Politics portal</a></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Party_politics" title="Template:Party politics"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Party_politics" title="Template talk:Party politics"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Party_politics&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Socialism</b> is a <a href="/wiki/Left-wing_politics" title="Left-wing politics">left-wing</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Economic_ideology" title="Economic ideology">economic philosophy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Political_movement" title="Political movement">movement</a> encompassing a range of <a href="/wiki/Economic_system" title="Economic system">economic systems</a> characterized by the dominance of <a href="/wiki/Social_ownership" title="Social ownership">social ownership</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup> of the <a href="/wiki/Means_of_production" title="Means of production">means of production</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oxfordcomp_4-0"><a href="#cite_note-oxfordcomp-4">[4]</a></sup> as opposed to <a href="/wiki/Private_property" title="Private property">private ownership</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHorvatMichie20001515–1516_5-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHorvatMichie20001515–1516-5">[5]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEArnold19947–8_6-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEArnold19947–8-6">[6]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oxfordcomp_4-1"><a href="#cite_note-oxfordcomp-4">[4]</a></sup> As a term, it describes the <a href="/wiki/Economic_ideology" title="Economic ideology">economic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Political_philosophy" title="Political philosophy">political</a> and <a href="/wiki/Social_theory" title="Social theory">social</a> theories and <a href="/wiki/Political_movement" title="Political movement">movements</a> associated with the implementation of such systems.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Socialism_at_The_Free_dictionary_7-0"><a href="#cite_note-Socialism_at_The_Free_dictionary-7">[7]</a></sup> Social ownership can be <a href="/wiki/State_ownership" title="State ownership">state/public</a>, <a href="/wiki/Community_ownership" title="Community ownership">community</a>, <a href="/wiki/Collective_ownership" title="Collective ownership">collective</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cooperative" title="Cooperative">cooperative</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Employee_stock_ownership#Employee_ownership" title="Employee stock ownership">employee</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Horvat_Page_1516_8-0"><a href="#cite_note-Horvat_Page_1516-8">[8]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup> While no single definition encapsulates the many <a href="/wiki/Types_of_socialism" title="Types of socialism">types of socialism</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELambDocherty20061_10-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELambDocherty20061-10">[10]</a></sup> social ownership is the one common element.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBusky20002_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBusky20002-11">[11]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEArnold19947–8_6-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEArnold19947–8-6">[6]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oxfordcomp_4-2"><a href="#cite_note-oxfordcomp-4">[4]</a></sup> Different types of socialism vary based on the role of markets and planning in resource allocation, on the structure of management in organizations, and from below or from above approaches, with some socialists favouring a party, state, or <a href="/wiki/Technocracy" title="Technocracy">technocratic</a>-driven approach. Socialists disagree on whether government, particularly existing government, is the correct vehicle for change.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nove_12-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nove-12">[12]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
</p><p>Socialist systems are divided into <a href="/wiki/Economic_planning" title="Economic planning">non-market</a> and <a href="/wiki/Market_(economics)" title="Market (economics)">market</a> forms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kolb_14-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kolb-14">[14]</a></sup> Non-market socialism substitutes <a href="/wiki/Factor_market" title="Factor market">factor markets</a> and often <a href="/wiki/Money" title="Money">money</a> with integrated <a href="/wiki/Economic_planning" title="Economic planning">economic planning</a> and engineering or technical criteria based on <a href="/wiki/Calculation_in_kind" title="Calculation in kind">calculation performed in-kind</a>, thereby producing a different economic mechanism that functions according to different <a href="/wiki/Law_of_value" title="Law of value">economic laws</a> and <a href="/wiki/System_dynamics" title="System dynamics">dynamics</a> than those of <a href="/wiki/Capitalism" title="Capitalism">capitalism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup> A non-market socialist system seeks to eliminate the perceived <a href="/wiki/Criticism_of_capitalism#Inefficiency,_irrationality,_and_unpredictability" title="Criticism of capitalism">inefficiencies, irrationalities, unpredictability</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Financial_crisis" title="Financial crisis">crises</a> that socialists traditionally associate with <a href="/wiki/Capital_accumulation" title="Capital accumulation">capital accumulation</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Profit_(economics)" title="Profit (economics)">profit</a> system in capitalism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> By contrast, <a href="/wiki/Market_socialism" title="Market socialism">market socialism</a> retains the use of monetary prices, factor markets and in some cases the <a href="/wiki/Profit_motive" title="Profit motive">profit motive</a>, with respect to the operation of socially owned enterprises and the allocation of capital goods between them. Profits generated by these firms would be controlled directly by the workforce of each firm or accrue to society at large in the form of a <a href="/wiki/Social_dividend" title="Social dividend">social dividend</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Social_Dividend_versus_Basic_Income_Guarantee_in_Market_Socialism,_2004_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-Social_Dividend_versus_Basic_Income_Guarantee_in_Market_Socialism,_2004-17">[17]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Anarchism" title="Anarchism">Anarchism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Libertarian_socialism" title="Libertarian socialism">libertarian socialism</a> oppose the use of the state as a means to establish socialism, favouring <a href="/wiki/Decentralization#Libertarian_socialism" title="Decentralization">decentralisation</a> above all, whether to establish non-market socialism or market socialism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p>Socialist politics has been both internationalist and nationalist; organised through political parties and opposed to party politics; at times overlapping with trade unions and at other times independent and critical of them, and present in both industrialised and developing nations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Social_democracy" title="Social democracy">Social democracy</a> originated within the socialist movement,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> supporting <a href="/wiki/Economic_interventionism" title="Economic interventionism">economic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Social_interventionism" title="Social interventionism">social interventions</a> to promote <a href="/wiki/Social_justice" title="Social justice">social justice</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> While retaining socialism as a long-term goal,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> since the post-war period it has come to embrace a <a href="/wiki/Keynesian_economics" title="Keynesian economics">Keynesian</a> <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed economy</a> within a predominantly developed capitalist <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">market economy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Liberal_democracy" title="Liberal democracy">liberal democratic</a> polity that expands state intervention to include <a href="/wiki/Redistribution_of_income_and_wealth" title="Redistribution of income and wealth">income redistribution</a>, <a href="/wiki/Regulatory_economics" title="Regulatory economics">regulation</a>, and a <a href="/wiki/Welfare_state" title="Welfare state">welfare state</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Economic_democracy" title="Economic democracy">Economic democracy</a> proposes a sort of market socialism, with more democratic control of companies, currencies, investments and natural resources.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup>
</p><p>The socialist <a href="/wiki/Political_movement" title="Political movement">political movement</a> includes a set of political philosophies that originated in the revolutionary movements of the mid-to-late 18th century and out of concern for the social problems that were associated with capitalism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELambDocherty20061_10-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELambDocherty20061-10">[10]</a></sup> By the late 19th century, after the work of <a href="/wiki/Karl_Marx" title="Karl Marx">Karl Marx</a> and his collaborator <a href="/wiki/Friedrich_Engels" title="Friedrich Engels">Friedrich Engels</a>, socialism had come to signify <a href="/wiki/Anti-capitalism" title="Anti-capitalism">opposition to capitalism</a> and advocacy for a <a href="/wiki/Post-capitalism" title="Post-capitalism">post-capitalist</a> system based on some form of social ownership of the means of production.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Anthony_Giddens_1994,_p._71_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-Anthony_Giddens_1994,_p._71-30">[30]</a></sup> By the early 1920s, <a href="/wiki/Communism" title="Communism">communism</a> and social democracy had become the two dominant political tendencies within the international socialist movement,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup> with socialism itself becoming the most influential secular movement of the 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Party" title="Socialist Party">Socialist parties</a> and ideas remain a political force with varying degrees of power and influence on all continents, heading national governments in many countries around the world. Today, many socialists have also adopted the causes of other social movements such as <a href="/wiki/Socialist_feminism" title="Socialist feminism">feminism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eco-socialism" title="Eco-socialism">environmentalism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Progressivism" title="Progressivism">progressivism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup>
</p><p>While the emergence of the Soviet Union as the world's first nominally <a href="/wiki/Socialist_state" title="Socialist state">socialist state</a> led to socialism's widespread association with the <a href="/wiki/Soviet-type_economic_planning" title="Soviet-type economic planning">Soviet economic model</a>, several scholars posit that in practice, the model functioned as a form of <a href="/wiki/State_capitalism" title="State capitalism">state capitalism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chomsky_1986_34-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chomsky_1986-34">[34]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-State_Capitalism_in_the_Soviet_Union,_2001_35-0"><a href="#cite_note-State_Capitalism_in_the_Soviet_Union,_2001-35">[35]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fitzgibbons_2002_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fitzgibbons_2002-36">[36]</a></sup> Several academics, political commentators, and scholars have distinguished between <a href="/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism" title="Authoritarian socialism">authoritarian socialist</a> and <a href="/wiki/Democratic_socialism" title="Democratic socialism">democratic socialist</a> states, with the first representing the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bloc" title="Eastern Bloc">Eastern Bloc</a> and the latter representing <a href="/wiki/Western_Bloc" title="Western Bloc">Western Bloc</a> countries which have been democratically governed by socialist parties such as Britain, France, Sweden, and Western countries in general, among others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup> However, following the end of the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>, many of these countries have moved away from socialism as a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neoliberal" title="Neoliberal">neoliberal</a> consensus replaced the social democratic consensus in the advanced capitalist world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup>
</p>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-34"><a href="#Politics"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Politics</span></a>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Etymology">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>For Andrew Vincent, "[t]he word 'socialism' finds its root in the Latin <span title="Latin-language text"><i lang="la">sociare</i></span>, which means to combine or to share. The related, more technical term in Roman and then medieval law was <span title="Latin-language text"><i lang="la">societas</i></span>. This latter word could mean companionship and fellowship as well as the more legalistic idea of a consensual contract between freemen".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ehrerbietige_Vorstellung_und_Einladung_an_meine_lieben_Mitmenschen.pdf"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1758" data-file-width="2862" decoding="async" height="184" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Ehrerbietige_Vorstellung_und_Einladung_an_meine_lieben_Mitmenschen.pdf/page1-300px-Ehrerbietige_Vorstellung_und_Einladung_an_meine_lieben_Mitmenschen.pdf.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Ehrerbietige_Vorstellung_und_Einladung_an_meine_lieben_Mitmenschen.pdf/page1-450px-Ehrerbietige_Vorstellung_und_Einladung_an_meine_lieben_Mitmenschen.pdf.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Ehrerbietige_Vorstellung_und_Einladung_an_meine_lieben_Mitmenschen.pdf/page1-600px-Ehrerbietige_Vorstellung_und_Einladung_an_meine_lieben_Mitmenschen.pdf.jpg 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ehrerbietige_Vorstellung_und_Einladung_an_meine_lieben_Mitmenschen.pdf" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Utopian_socialist" title="Utopian socialist">Utopian socialist</a> pamphlet of <a href="/wiki/Rudolf_Sutermeister" title="Rudolf Sutermeister">Rudolf Sutermeister</a></div></div></div>
<p>Initial use of <i>socialism</i> was claimed by <a href="/wiki/Pierre_Leroux" title="Pierre Leroux">Pierre Leroux</a>, who alleged he first used the term in the Parisian journal <span title="French-language text"><i lang="fr"><a href="/wiki/Le_Globe" title="Le Globe">Le Globe</a></i></span> in 1832.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kołakowski2005_41-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kołakowski2005-41">[41]</a></sup> Leroux was a follower of <a href="/wiki/Henri_de_Saint-Simon" title="Henri de Saint-Simon">Henri de Saint-Simon</a>, one of the founders of what would later be labelled <a href="/wiki/Utopian_socialism" title="Utopian socialism">utopian socialism</a>. Socialism contrasted with the <a href="/wiki/Liberalism" title="Liberalism">liberal</a> doctrine of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Liberal_individualism" title="Liberal individualism">individualism</a> that emphasized the moral worth of the individual whilst stressing that people act or should act as if they are in isolation from one another. The original utopian socialists condemned this doctrine of individualism for failing to address social concerns during the <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Revolution" title="Industrial Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Poverty" title="Poverty">poverty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oppression" title="Oppression">oppression</a>, and vast <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wealth_inequality" title="Wealth inequality">wealth inequality</a>. They viewed their society as harming community life by basing society on competition. They presented socialism as an alternative to liberal individualism based on the shared ownership of resources.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Marvin_Perry_1600,_p._540_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-Marvin_Perry_1600,_p._540-42">[42]</a></sup> Saint-Simon proposed <a href="/wiki/Economic_planning" title="Economic planning">economic planning</a>, scientific administration and the application of scientific understanding to the organisation of society. By contrast, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Owen" title="Robert Owen">Robert Owen</a> proposed to organise production and ownership via <a href="/wiki/Cooperative" title="Cooperative">cooperatives</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Marvin_Perry_1600,_p._540_42-1"><a href="#cite_note-Marvin_Perry_1600,_p._540-42">[42]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> <i>Socialism</i> is also attributed in France to <a href="/wiki/Marie_Roch_Louis_Reybaud" title="Marie Roch Louis Reybaud">Marie Roch Louis Reybaud</a> while in Britain it is attributed to Owen, who became one of the fathers of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cooperative_movement" title="Cooperative movement">cooperative movement</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p><p>The definition and usage of <i>socialism</i> settled by the 1860s, replacing <i>associationist</i>, <i>co-operative</i>, and <i>mutualist</i> that had been used as synonyms while <i>communism</i> fell out of use during this period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Williams_1983_288_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-Williams_1983_288-46">[46]</a></sup> An early distinction between <i><a href="/wiki/Communism" title="Communism">communism</a></i> and <i>socialism</i> was that the latter aimed to only socialise production while the former aimed to socialise both <a href="/wiki/Production_(economics)" title="Production (economics)">production</a> and <a href="/wiki/Consumption_(economics)" title="Consumption (economics)">consumption</a> (in the form of free access to final goods).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Steele_1992_43_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-Steele_1992_43-47">[47]</a></sup> By 1888, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marxists" title="Marxists">Marxists</a> employed <i>socialism</i> in place of <i>communism</i> as the latter had come to be considered an old-fashioned synonym for <i>socialism</i>. It was not until after the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bolshevik_Revolution" title="Bolshevik Revolution">Bolshevik Revolution</a> that <i>socialism</i> was appropriated by <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin" title="Vladimir Lenin">Vladimir Lenin</a> to mean a stage between <a href="/wiki/Capitalism" title="Capitalism">capitalism</a> and communism. He used it to defend the Bolshevik program from Marxist criticism that Russia's <a href="/wiki/Productive_forces" title="Productive forces">productive forces</a> were not sufficiently developed for communism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Steele_1992_44-45_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-Steele_1992_44-45-48">[48]</a></sup> The distinction between <i>communism</i> and <i>socialism</i> became salient in 1918 after the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Social_Democratic_Labour_Party" title="Russian Social Democratic Labour Party">Russian Social Democratic Labour Party</a> renamed itself to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All-Russian_Communist_Party" title="All-Russian Communist Party">All-Russian Communist Party</a>, interpreting <i>communism</i> specifically to mean socialists who supported the politics and theories of <a href="/wiki/Bolshevism" title="Bolshevism">Bolshevism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leninism" title="Leninism">Leninism</a> and later that of <a href="/wiki/Marxism%E2%80%93Leninism" title="Marxism–Leninism">Marxism–Leninism</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> although <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Communist_parties" title="Communist parties">communist parties</a> continued to describe themselves as socialists dedicated to socialism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> According to <i>The Oxford Handbook of Karl Marx</i>, "Marx used many terms to refer to a post-capitalist society—positive humanism, socialism, Communism, realm of free individuality, free association of producers, etc. He used these terms completely interchangeably. The notion that 'socialism' and 'Communism' are distinct historical stages is alien to his work and only entered the lexicon of Marxism after his death".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup>
</p><p>In <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian_Europe" title="Christian Europe">Christian Europe</a>, communists were believed to have adopted <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">atheism</a>. In Protestant England, <i>communism</i> was too close to the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Roman Catholic</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Communion_rite" title="Communion rite">communion rite</a>, hence <i>socialist</i> was the preferred term.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> Engels wrote that in 1848, when <i><a href="/wiki/The_Communist_Manifesto" title="The Communist Manifesto">The Communist Manifesto</a></i> was published, socialism was respectable in Europe while communism was not. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Owenites" title="Owenites">Owenites</a> in England and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fourierists" title="Fourierists">Fourierists</a> in France were considered respectable socialists while working-class movements that "proclaimed the necessity of total social change" denoted themselves <i>communists</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> This branch of socialism produced the communist work of <a href="/wiki/%C3%89tienne_Cabet" title="Étienne Cabet">Étienne Cabet</a> in France and <a href="/wiki/Wilhelm_Weitling" title="Wilhelm Weitling">Wilhelm Weitling</a> in Germany.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> British moral philosopher <a href="/wiki/John_Stuart_Mill" title="John Stuart Mill">John Stuart Mill</a> discussed a form of economic socialism within a liberal context that would later be known as <a href="/wiki/Liberal_socialism" title="Liberal socialism">liberal socialism</a>. In later editions of his <i><a href="/wiki/Principles_of_Political_Economy" title="Principles of Political Economy">Principles of Political Economy</a></i> (1848), Mill posited that "as far as economic theory was concerned, there is nothing in principle in economic theory that precludes an economic order based on socialist policies"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> and promoted substituting capitalist <a href="/wiki/Business" title="Business">businesses</a> with <a href="/wiki/Worker_cooperative" title="Worker cooperative">worker cooperatives</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup> While democrats looked to the <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1848" title="Revolutions of 1848">Revolutions of 1848</a> as a <a href="/wiki/Democratic_revolution" title="Democratic revolution">democratic revolution</a> which in the long run ensured <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Liberty,_equality,_and_fraternity" title="Liberty, equality, and fraternity">liberty, equality, and fraternity</a>, Marxists denounced it as a betrayal of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Working-class" title="Working-class">working-class</a> ideals by a <a href="/wiki/Bourgeoisie" title="Bourgeoisie">bourgeoisie</a> indifferent to the <a href="/wiki/Proletariat" title="Proletariat">proletariat</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_socialism" title="History of socialism">History of socialism</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/History_of_anarchism" title="History of anarchism">History of anarchism</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_communism" title="History of communism">History of communism</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_socialism">Early socialism</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Early socialism">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1848" title="Revolutions of 1848">Revolutions of 1848</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Classical_economics" title="Classical economics">Classical economics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pre-Marxist_communism" title="Pre-Marxist communism">Pre-Marxist communism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pre-Marx_socialists" title="Pre-Marx socialists">Pre-Marx socialists</a>, <a href="/wiki/Political_economy" title="Political economy">Political economy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ricardian_socialism" title="Ricardian socialism">Ricardian socialism</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Charles_Fourier_(by_Hans_F._Helmolt).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="535" data-file-width="418" decoding="async" height="218" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Charles_Fourier_%28by_Hans_F._Helmolt%29.jpg/170px-Charles_Fourier_%28by_Hans_F._Helmolt%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Charles_Fourier_%28by_Hans_F._Helmolt%29.jpg/255px-Charles_Fourier_%28by_Hans_F._Helmolt%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Charles_Fourier_%28by_Hans_F._Helmolt%29.jpg/340px-Charles_Fourier_%28by_Hans_F._Helmolt%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Charles_Fourier_(by_Hans_F._Helmolt).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Charles_Fourier" title="Charles Fourier">Charles Fourier</a>, influential early <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/French_socialist" title="French socialist">French socialist</a> thinker</div></div></div>
<p>Socialist models and ideas espousing common or public ownership have existed since antiquity. The economy of the 3rd century BCE <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mauryan_Empire" title="Mauryan Empire">Mauryan Empire</a> of India, an absolute monarchy, has been described by some scholars as "a socialized monarchy" and "a sort of state socialism" due to "nationalisation of industries".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> Other scholars have suggested that elements of socialist thought were present in the politics of classical <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek_philosophy" title="Ancient Greek philosophy">Greek philosophers</a> <a href="/wiki/Plato" title="Plato">Plato</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Aristotle" title="Aristotle">Aristotle</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mazdak" title="Mazdak">Mazdak the Younger</a> (died c. 524 or 528 CE), a Persian communal proto-socialist,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> instituted communal possessions and advocated the public good. <a href="/wiki/Abu_Dharr_al-Ghifari" title="Abu Dharr al-Ghifari">Abu Dharr al-Ghifari</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Companions_of_the_Prophet" title="Companions of the Prophet">Companion</a> of <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a>, is credited by multiple authors as a principal antecedent of <a href="/wiki/Islamic_socialism" title="Islamic socialism">Islamic socialism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup> The teachings of <a href="/wiki/Jesus" title="Jesus">Jesus</a> are frequently described as socialist, especially by Christian socialists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> <a class="external text" href="https://bible.oremus.org/?passage=Acts%204:35&amp;version=nrsv" rel="nofollow">Acts 4:35</a> records that in the <a href="/wiki/History_of_Christianity" title="History of Christianity">early church</a> in <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a> "[n]o one claimed that any of their possessions was their own", although the pattern soon disappears from <a href="/wiki/Church_history" title="Church history">church history</a> except within <a href="/wiki/Monasticism" title="Monasticism">monasticism</a>. <a href="/wiki/Christian_socialism" title="Christian socialism">Christian socialism</a> was one of the founding threads of the British <a href="/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK)" title="Labour Party (UK)">Labour Party</a> and is claimed to begin with the <a href="/wiki/Peasants%27_Revolt" title="Peasants' Revolt">uprising</a> of <a href="/wiki/Wat_Tyler" title="Wat Tyler">Wat Tyler</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_Ball_(priest)" title="John Ball (priest)">John Ball</a> in the 14th century CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup> After the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">French Revolution</a>, activists and theorists such as <a href="/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois-No%C3%ABl_Babeuf" title="François-Noël Babeuf">François-Noël Babeuf</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C3%89tienne-Gabriel_Morelly" title="Étienne-Gabriel Morelly">Étienne-Gabriel Morelly</a>, <a href="/wiki/Philippe_Buonarroti" title="Philippe Buonarroti">Philippe Buonarroti</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Auguste_Blanqui" title="Auguste Blanqui">Auguste Blanqui</a> influenced the early French labour and socialist movements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-George_Thomas_Kurian_2011_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-George_Thomas_Kurian_2011-68">[68]</a></sup> In Britain, <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Paine" title="Thomas Paine">Thomas Paine</a> proposed a detailed plan to tax property owners to pay for the needs of the poor in <i><a href="/wiki/Agrarian_Justice" title="Agrarian Justice">Agrarian Justice</a></i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Charles_Hall_(economist)" title="Charles Hall (economist)">Charles Hall</a> wrote <i>The Effects of Civilization on the People in European States</i>, denouncing capitalism's effects on the poor of his time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blaug_1986_358_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-Blaug_1986_358-70">[70]</a></sup> This work influenced the utopian schemes of <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Spence" title="Thomas Spence">Thomas Spence</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first self-conscious socialist movements developed in the 1820s and 1830s. Groups such as the <a href="/wiki/Fourierism" title="Fourierism">Fourierists</a>, <a href="/wiki/Owenism" title="Owenism">Owenites</a> and <a href="/wiki/Saint-Simonianism" title="Saint-Simonianism">Saint-Simonians</a> provided a series of analyses and interpretations of society. Especially the Owenites overlapped with other working-class movements such as the <a href="/wiki/Chartism" title="Chartism">Chartists</a> in the United Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup> The Chartists gathered significant numbers around the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/People%27s_Charter_of_1838" title="People's Charter of 1838">People's Charter of 1838</a> which sought democratic reforms focused on the extension of suffrage to all male adults. Leaders in the movement called for a more equitable distribution of income and better living conditions for the working classes. The first trade unions and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Consumer_cooperative" title="Consumer cooperative">consumer cooperative</a> societies followed the Chartist movement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pierre-Joseph_Proudhon" title="Pierre-Joseph Proudhon">Pierre-Joseph Proudhon</a> proposed his philosophy of <a href="/wiki/Mutualism_(economic_theory)" title="Mutualism (economic theory)">mutualism</a> in which "everyone had an equal claim, either alone or as part of a small cooperative, to possess and use land and other resources as needed to make a living".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup> Other currents inspired <a href="/wiki/Christian_socialism" title="Christian socialism">Christian socialism</a> "often in Britain and then usually coming out of left liberal politics and a romantic anti-industrialism"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-George_Thomas_Kurian_2011_68-1"><a href="#cite_note-George_Thomas_Kurian_2011-68">[68]</a></sup> which produced theorists such as <a href="/wiki/Edward_Bellamy" title="Edward Bellamy">Edward Bellamy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Charles_Kingsley" title="Charles Kingsley">Charles Kingsley</a> and <a href="/wiki/Frederick_Denison_Maurice" title="Frederick Denison Maurice">Frederick Denison Maurice</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceC_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceC-75">[75]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first advocates of socialism favoured social levelling in order to create a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Meritocratic" title="Meritocratic">meritocratic</a> or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Technocratic" title="Technocratic">technocratic</a> society based on individual talent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fsmitha.com_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-fsmitha.com-76">[76]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Henri_de_Saint-Simon" title="Henri de Saint-Simon">Henri de Saint-Simon</a> was fascinated by the potential of science and technology and advocated a socialist society that would eliminate the disorderly aspects of capitalism based on equal opportunities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources" title="Wikipedia:Reliable sources"><span title="The material near this tag may rely on an unreliable source. (December 2011)">unreliable source?</span></a></i>]</sup> He sought a society in which each person was ranked according to his or her capacities and rewarded according to his or her work.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fsmitha.com_76-1"><a href="#cite_note-fsmitha.com-76">[76]</a></sup> His key focus was on administrative efficiency and industrialism and a belief that science was essential to progress.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENewman2005_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENewman2005-78">[78]</a></sup> This was accompanied by a desire for a rationally organised economy based on planning and geared towards large-scale scientific and material progress.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fsmitha.com_76-2"><a href="#cite_note-fsmitha.com-76">[76]</a></sup>
</p><p>West European social critics, including <a href="/wiki/Louis_Blanc" title="Louis Blanc">Louis Blanc</a>, <a href="/wiki/Charles_Fourier" title="Charles Fourier">Charles Fourier</a>, Charles Hall, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Owen" title="Robert Owen">Robert Owen</a>, Pierre-Joseph Proudhon and Saint-Simon were the first modern socialists who criticised the poverty and inequality of the <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Revolution" title="Industrial Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a>. They advocated reform, Owen advocating the transformation of society to small communities without <a href="/wiki/Private_property" title="Private property">private property</a>. Owen's contribution to modern socialism was his claim that individual actions and characteristics were largely determined by their social environment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENewman2005_78-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENewman2005-78">[78]</a></sup> On the other hand, Fourier advocated <a href="/wiki/Phalanst%C3%A8re" title="Phalanstère">Phalanstères</a> (communities that respected individual desires, including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sexual_preference" title="Sexual preference">sexual preferences</a>), affinities and creativity and saw that work has to be made enjoyable for people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup> Owen and Fourier's ideas were practiced in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Intentional_communities" title="Intentional communities">intentional communities</a> around Europe and North America in the mid-19th century.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Paris_Commune">Paris Commune</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Paris Commune">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Paris_Commune" title="Paris Commune">Paris Commune</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Commune_28_mars.jpeg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="499" data-file-width="472" decoding="async" height="233" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Commune_28_mars.jpeg/220px-Commune_28_mars.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Commune_28_mars.jpeg/330px-Commune_28_mars.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Commune_28_mars.jpeg/440px-Commune_28_mars.jpeg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Commune_28_mars.jpeg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The celebration of the election of the Commune on 28 March 1871—the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Commune" title="Paris Commune">Paris Commune</a> was a major early implementation of socialist ideas</div></div></div>
<p>The Paris Commune was a government that ruled Paris from 18 March (formally, from 28 March) to 28 May 1871. The Commune was the result of an uprising in Paris after France was defeated in the <a href="/wiki/Franco-Prussian_War" title="Franco-Prussian War">Franco-Prussian War</a>. The Commune elections were held on 26 March. They elected a Commune council of 92 members, one member for each 20,000 residents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup>
</p><p>Because the Commune was able to meet on fewer than 60 days in total, only a few decrees were actually implemented. These included the <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_church_and_state" title="Separation of church and state">separation of church and state</a>; the remission of rents owed for the period of the siege (during which payment had been suspended); the abolition of <a href="/wiki/Shift_work" title="Shift work">night work</a> in the hundreds of Paris <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bakeries" title="Bakeries">bakeries</a>; the granting of pensions to the unmarried companions and children of National Guards killed on active service; and the free return of all workmen's tools and household items valued up to 20 francs that had been pledged during the siege.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Milza,_Pierre,_La_Commune_81-0"><a href="#cite_note-Milza,_Pierre,_La_Commune-81">[81]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="First_International">First International</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: First International">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/International_Workingmen%27s_Association" title="International Workingmen's Association">International Workingmen's Association</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bakunin_speaking.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1721" data-file-width="1263" decoding="async" height="259" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Bakunin_speaking.png/190px-Bakunin_speaking.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Bakunin_speaking.png/285px-Bakunin_speaking.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Bakunin_speaking.png/380px-Bakunin_speaking.png 2x" width="190"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bakunin_speaking.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Bakunin" title="Mikhail Bakunin">Mikhail Bakunin</a> speaking to members of the <a href="/wiki/International_Workingmen%27s_Association" title="International Workingmen's Association">International Workingmen's Association</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Basel_Congress_(1869)" title="Basel Congress (1869)">Basel Congress</a> in 1869</div></div></div>
<p>In 1864, the First International was founded in London. It united diverse revolutionary currents, including socialists such as the French followers of Proudhon,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Blanquism" title="Blanquism">Blanquists</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Philadelphes" title="Philadelphes">Philadelphes</a>, English <a href="/wiki/Trade_union" title="Trade union">trade unionists</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Social_democrats" title="Social democrats">social democrats</a>. In 1865 and 1866, it held a preliminary conference and had its first congress in <a href="/wiki/Geneva" title="Geneva">Geneva</a>, respectively. Due to their wide variety of philosophies, conflict immediately erupted. The first objections to Marx came from the mutualists who opposed <a href="/wiki/State_socialism" title="State socialism">state socialism</a>. Shortly after <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Bakunin" title="Mikhail Bakunin">Mikhail Bakunin</a> and his followers joined in 1868, the First International became polarised into camps headed by Marx and Bakunin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> The clearest differences between the groups emerged over their proposed strategies for achieving their visions. The First International became the first major international forum for the promulgation of socialist ideas.
</p><p>Bakunin's followers were called <a href="/wiki/Collectivist_anarchism" title="Collectivist anarchism">collectivists</a> and sought to collectivise ownership of the means of production while retaining payment proportional to the amount and kind of labour of each individual. Like Proudhonists, they asserted the right of each individual to the product of his labour and to be remunerated for his particular contribution to production. By contrast, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anarcho-communists" title="Anarcho-communists">anarcho-communists</a> sought collective ownership of both the means and the products of labour. As <a href="/wiki/Errico_Malatesta" title="Errico Malatesta">Errico Malatesta</a> put it, "instead of running the risk of making a confusion in trying to distinguish what you and I each do, let us all work and put everything in common. In this way each will give to society all that his strength permits until enough is produced for every one; and each will take all that he needs, limiting his needs only in those things of which there is not yet plenty for every one".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dwardmac.pitzer.edu_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-dwardmac.pitzer.edu-84">[84]</a></sup> Anarcho-communism as a coherent economic-political philosophy was first formulated in the Italian section of the First International by Malatesta, <a href="/wiki/Carlo_Cafiero" title="Carlo Cafiero">Carlo Cafiero</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emilio_Covelli" title="Emilio Covelli">Emilio Covelli</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Andrea_Costa" title="Andrea Costa">Andrea Costa</a> and other ex-<a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Mazzini" title="Giuseppe Mazzini">Mazzinian</a> republicans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nunzio_Pernicious_pp._111-113_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nunzio_Pernicious_pp._111-113-85">[85]</a></sup> Out of respect for Bakunin, they did not make their differences with collectivist anarchism explicit until after his death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marxists.org_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-marxists.org-86">[86]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Syndicalism" title="Syndicalism">Syndicalism</a> emerged in France inspired in part by Proudhon and later by Pelloutier and <a href="/wiki/Georges_Sorel" title="Georges Sorel">Georges Sorel</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceB_87-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceB-87">[87]</a></sup> It developed at the end of the 19th century out of the French trade-union movement (<i>syndicat</i> is the French word for trade union). It was a significant force in Italy and Spain in the early 20th century until it was crushed by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fascist" title="Fascist">fascist</a> regimes in those countries. In the United States, syndicalism appeared in the guise of the <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Workers_of_the_World" title="Industrial Workers of the World">Industrial Workers of the World</a>, or "Wobblies", founded in 1905.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceB_87-1"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceB-87">[87]</a></sup> Syndicalism is an <a href="/wiki/Economic_system" title="Economic system">economic system</a> that organises industries into <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Confederations" title="Confederations">confederations</a> (syndicates)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup> and the economy is managed by negotiation between specialists and worker representatives of each field, comprising multiple non-competitive categorised units.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> Syndicalism is a form of communism and economic <a href="/wiki/Corporatism" title="Corporatism">corporatism</a>, but also refers to the political movement and tactics used to bring about this type of system. An influential anarchist movement based on syndicalist ideas is <a href="/wiki/Anarcho-syndicalism" title="Anarcho-syndicalism">anarcho-syndicalism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_Workers%27_Association_%E2%80%93_Asociaci%C3%B3n_Internacional_de_los_Trabajadores" title="International Workers' Association – Asociación Internacional de los Trabajadores">International Workers Association</a> is an international anarcho-syndicalist federation of various labour unions.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Fabian_Society" title="Fabian Society">Fabian Society</a> is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_socialism_in_Great_Britain" title="History of socialism in Great Britain">British socialist</a> organisation established to advance socialism via <a href="/wiki/Gradualism" title="Gradualism">gradualist</a> and <a href="/wiki/Reformism" title="Reformism">reformist</a> means.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gt76_91-0"><a href="#cite_note-gt76-91">[91]</a></sup> The society laid many foundations of the <a href="/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK)" title="Labour Party (UK)">Labour Party</a> and subsequently affected the policies of states emerging from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Decolonisation" title="Decolonisation">decolonisation</a> of the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a>, most notably India and Singapore. Originally, the Fabian Society was committed to the establishment of a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Socialist_economy" title="Socialist economy">socialist economy</a>, alongside a commitment to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_imperialism" title="British imperialism">British imperialism</a> as a progressive and modernising force.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Discovering_Imperialism:_Social_Democracy_to_World_War_I,_p._249_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-Discovering_Imperialism:_Social_Democracy_to_World_War_I,_p._249-92">[92]</a></sup> Later, the society functioned primarily as a <a href="/wiki/Think_tank" title="Think tank">think tank</a> and is one of fifteen <a href="/wiki/Socialist_society_(Labour_Party)" title="Socialist society (Labour Party)">socialist societies</a> affiliated with the Labour Party. Similar societies exist in Australia (the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Fabian_Society" title="Australian Fabian Society">Australian Fabian Society</a>), in Canada (the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Douglas-Coldwell_Foundation" title="Douglas-Coldwell Foundation">Douglas-Coldwell Foundation</a> and the now disbanded <a href="/wiki/League_for_Social_Reconstruction" title="League for Social Reconstruction">League for Social Reconstruction</a>) and in New Zealand.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Guild_socialism" title="Guild socialism">Guild socialism</a> is a political movement advocating <a href="/wiki/Workers%27_control" title="Workers' control">workers' control</a> of industry through the medium of trade-related <a href="/wiki/Guild" title="Guild">guilds</a> "in an implied contractual relationship with the public".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup> It originated in the United Kingdom and was at its most influential in the first quarter of the 20th century. Inspired by <a href="/wiki/Guild" title="Guild">medieval guilds</a>, theorists such as <a href="/wiki/Samuel_George_Hobson" title="Samuel George Hobson">Samuel George Hobson</a> and <a href="/wiki/G._D._H._Cole" title="G. D. H. Cole">G. D. H. Cole</a> advocated the public ownership of industries and their workforces' organisation into guilds, each of which under the democratic control of its trade union. Guild socialists were less inclined than Fabians to invest power in a state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceB_87-2"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceB-87">[87]</a></sup> At some point, like the American <a href="/wiki/Knights_of_Labor" title="Knights of Labor">Knights of Labor</a>, guild socialism wanted to abolish the wage system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto1_94-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-94">[94]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Second_International">Second International</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Second International">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Second_International" title="Second International">Second International</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Internationalist%E2%80%93defencist_schism" title="Internationalist–defencist schism">Internationalist–defencist schism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Proletarian_internationalism" title="Proletarian internationalism">Proletarian internationalism</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reformist%E2%80%93revolutionary_dispute" title="Reformist–revolutionary dispute">Reformist–revolutionary dispute</a>, <a href="/wiki/Revolutionary_defeatism" title="Revolutionary defeatism">Revolutionary defeatism</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Social_chauvinism" title="Social chauvinism">Social chauvinism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Social_patriotism" title="Social patriotism">Social patriotism</a></div>
<p>As the ideas of Marx and Engels gained acceptance, particularly in central Europe, socialists sought to unite in an international organisation. In 1889 (the centennial of the French Revolution), the Second International was founded, with 384 delegates from twenty countries representing about 300 labour and socialist organisations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> Engels was elected honorary president at the third congress in 1893. Anarchists were banned, mainly due to pressure from Marxists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWoodcock1962263–264_96-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWoodcock1962263–264-96">[96]</a></sup> It has been argued that at some point the Second International turned "into a battleground over the issue of <a href="/wiki/Libertarian_socialism" title="Libertarian socialism">libertarian</a> versus <a href="/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism" title="Authoritarian socialism">authoritarian socialism</a>. Not only did they effectively present themselves as champions of minority rights; they also provoked the German Marxists into demonstrating a dictatorial intolerance which was a factor in preventing the British labour movement from following the Marxist direction indicated by such leaders as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/H._M._Hyndman" title="H. M. Hyndman">H. M. Hyndman</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWoodcock1962263–264_96-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWoodcock1962263–264-96">[96]</a></sup>
</p><p>Reformism arose as an alternative to revolution. <a href="/wiki/Eduard_Bernstein" title="Eduard Bernstein">Eduard Bernstein</a> was a leading <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Social_democrat" title="Social democrat">social democrat</a> in Germany who proposed the concept of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Evolutionary_socialism" title="Evolutionary socialism">evolutionary socialism</a>. Revolutionary socialists quickly targeted reformism: <a href="/wiki/Rosa_Luxemburg" title="Rosa Luxemburg">Rosa Luxemburg</a> condemned Bernstein's <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Evolutionary_Socialism" title="Evolutionary Socialism">Evolutionary Socialism</a></i> in her 1900 essay <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Social_Reform_or_Revolution" title="Social Reform or Revolution">Social Reform or Revolution</a>?</i> <a href="/wiki/Revolutionary_socialism" title="Revolutionary socialism">Revolutionary socialism</a> encompasses multiple social and political movements that may define "revolution" differently. The <a href="/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_Germany" title="Social Democratic Party of Germany">Social Democratic Party of Germany</a> (SPD) became the largest and most powerful socialist party in Europe, despite working illegally until the anti-socialist laws were dropped in 1890. In the 1893 elections, it gained 1,787,000 votes, a quarter of the total votes cast, according to Engels. In 1895, the year of his death, Engels emphasised <i><a href="/wiki/The_Communist_Manifesto" title="The Communist Manifesto">The Communist Manifesto</a>'</i>s emphasis on winning, as a first step, the "battle of democracy".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup>
</p><p>In South America, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Socialist_Party_of_Argentina" title="Socialist Party of Argentina">Socialist Party of Argentina</a> was established in the 1890s led by <a href="/wiki/Juan_B._Justo" title="Juan B. Justo">Juan B. Justo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nicol%C3%A1s_Repetto" title="Nicolás Repetto">Nicolás Repetto</a>, among others. It was the first <a href="/wiki/Political_party#Types_of_political_parties" title="Political party">mass party</a> in the country and in Latin America. The party affiliated itself with the Second International.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_20th_century">Early 20th century</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Early 20th century">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Biennio_Rosso" title="Biennio Rosso">Biennio Rosso</a>, <a href="/wiki/German_Revolution_of_1918%E2%80%931919" title="German Revolution of 1918–1919">German Revolution of 1918–1919</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_Revolution" title="Russian Revolution">Russian Revolution</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Revolution_of_1936" title="Spanish Revolution of 1936">Spanish Revolution of 1936</a>, and <a href="/wiki/World_communism" title="World communism">World communism</a></div>
<p>For four months in 1904, <a href="/wiki/Australian_Labor_Party" title="Australian Labor Party">Australian Labor Party</a> leader <a href="/wiki/Chris_Watson" title="Chris Watson">Chris Watson</a> was the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Australia" title="Prime Minister of Australia">Prime Minister</a> of the country. Watson thus became the head of the world's first socialist or social democratic parliamentary government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup> Australian historian <a href="/wiki/Geoffrey_Blainey" title="Geoffrey Blainey">Geoffrey Blainey</a> argues that the Labor Party was not socialist at all in the 1890s, and that socialist and collectivist elements only made their way in the party's platform in the early 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup>
</p><p>
In 1909, the first <a href="/wiki/Kibbutz" title="Kibbutz">Kibbutz</a> was established in Palestine<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup> by Russian Jewish Immigrants. The <a href="/wiki/Kibbutz_Movement" title="Kibbutz Movement">Kibbutz Movement</a> expanded through the 20th century following a doctrine of <a href="/wiki/Zionism" title="Zionism">Zionist</a> socialism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup> The British Labour Party first won seats in the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Commons" title="House of Commons">House of Commons</a> in 1902.</p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gramsci.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="408" data-file-width="288" decoding="async" height="241" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Gramsci.png/170px-Gramsci.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Gramsci.png/255px-Gramsci.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e6/Gramsci.png 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gramsci.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Antonio_Gramsci" title="Antonio Gramsci">Antonio Gramsci</a>, member of the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Socialist_Party" title="Italian Socialist Party">Italian Socialist Party</a> and later leader and theorist of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Italy" title="Communist Party of Italy">Communist Party of Italy</a></div></div></div><p>By 1917, the patriotism of <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> changed into <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Political_radicalism" title="Political radicalism">political radicalism</a> in Australia, most of Europe and the United States. Other socialist parties from around the world who were beginning to gain importance in their national politics in the early 20th century included the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Socialist_Party" title="Italian Socialist Party">Italian Socialist Party</a>, the <a href="/wiki/French_Section_of_the_Workers%27_International" title="French Section of the Workers' International">French Section of the Workers' International</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Socialist_Workers%27_Party" title="Spanish Socialist Workers' Party">Spanish Socialist Workers' Party</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Swedish_Social_Democratic_Party" title="Swedish Social Democratic Party">Swedish Social Democratic Party</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Social_Democratic_Labour_Party" title="Russian Social Democratic Labour Party">Russian Social Democratic Labour Party</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Party_(Argentina)" title="Socialist Party (Argentina)">Socialist Party</a> in Argentina, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Socialist_Workers%27_Party_(Chile)" title="Socialist Workers' Party (Chile)">Socialist Workers' Party</a> in Chile and the <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Party_of_America" title="Socialist Party of America">Socialist Party of America</a> in the United States.
</p><h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Russian_Revolution">Russian Revolution</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Russian Revolution">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/February_Revolution" title="February Revolution">February Revolution</a> and <a href="/wiki/October_Revolution" title="October Revolution">October Revolution</a></div>
<p>In February 1917, a revolution occurred in Russia. Workers, soldiers and peasants established <a href="/wiki/Soviet_(council)" title="Soviet (council)">soviets</a> (councils), the <a href="/wiki/Abdication_of_Nicholas_II" title="Abdication of Nicholas II">monarchy fell</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Russian_Provisional_Government" title="Russian Provisional Government">provisional government</a> convened pending the election of a <a href="/wiki/Constituent_assembly" title="Constituent assembly">constituent assembly</a>. In April of that year, <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin" title="Vladimir Lenin">Vladimir Lenin</a>, leader of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bolshevik" title="Bolshevik">Bolshevik</a> faction of <a href="/wiki/Russian_Social_Democratic_Labour_Party" title="Russian Social Democratic Labour Party">socialists in Russia</a> and known for his <a href="/wiki/Leninism" title="Leninism">profound and controversial expansions</a> of <a href="/wiki/Marxism" title="Marxism">Marxism</a>, was allowed to cross Germany to return from exile in Switzerland.
</p><p>Lenin had published <a href="/wiki/Imperialism,_the_Highest_Stage_of_Capitalism" title="Imperialism, the Highest Stage of Capitalism">essays</a> on his analysis of <a href="/wiki/Leninism#Imperialism" title="Leninism">imperialism</a>, the monopoly and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Globalisation" title="Globalisation">globalisation</a> phase of capitalism, as well as analyses on social conditions. He observed that as capitalism had further developed in Europe and America, the workers remained unable to gain <a href="/wiki/Class_consciousness" title="Class consciousness">class consciousness</a> so long as they were too busy working to pay their expenses. He therefore proposed that the social revolution would require the leadership of a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vanguard_party" title="Vanguard party">vanguard party</a> of class-conscious revolutionaries from the educated and politically active part of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup>
</p><p>Upon arriving in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Petrograd" title="Petrograd">Petrograd</a>, Lenin declared that the revolution in Russia had only begun, and that the next step was for the workers' <a href="/wiki/Soviet_(council)" title="Soviet (council)">soviets</a> to take full authority. He issued a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/April_Thesis" title="April Thesis">thesis</a> outlining the Bolshevik programme, including rejection of any legitimacy in the provisional government and advocacy for state power to be administered through the soviets. The Bolsheviks became the most influential force. On 7 November, the <a href="/wiki/Winter_Palace" title="Winter Palace">capitol of the provisional government</a> was stormed by <a href="/wiki/Red_Guards_(Russia)" title="Red Guards (Russia)">Bolshevik Red Guards</a> in what later was officially known in the Soviet Union as the Great October Socialist Revolution. The provisional government ended and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_Socialist_Federative_Soviet_Republic" title="Russian Socialist Federative Soviet Republic">Russian Socialist Federative Soviet Republic</a>—the world's first constitutionally socialist state—was established. On 25 January 1918, Lenin declared "Long live the world socialist revolution!" at the <a href="/wiki/Petrograd_Soviet" title="Petrograd Soviet">Petrograd Soviet</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup> and proposed an immediate armistice on all fronts and transferred the land of the landed proprietors, the crown and the monasteries to the peasant committees without compensation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup>
</p><p>The day after assuming executive power on 25 January, Lenin wrote <i>Draft Regulations on Workers' Control</i>, which granted workers control of businesses with more than five workers and office employees and access to all books, documents and stocks and whose decisions were to be "binding upon the owners of the enterprises".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup> Governing through the elected soviets and in alliance with the peasant-based <a href="/wiki/Left_Socialist-Revolutionaries" title="Left Socialist-Revolutionaries">Left Socialist-Revolutionaries</a>, the Bolshevik government began nationalising banks and industry; and disavowed the national debts of the deposed <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Romanov" title="Romanov">Romanov</a> royal régime. It <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sued_for_peace" title="Sued for peace">sued for peace</a>, withdrawing from World War I and convoked a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constituent_Assembly" title="Constituent Assembly">Constituent Assembly</a> in which the peasant <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Socialist-Revolutionary_Party" title="Socialist-Revolutionary Party">Socialist-Revolutionary Party</a> (SR) won a majority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Constituent Assembly elected SR leader <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Victor_Chernov" title="Victor Chernov">Victor Chernov</a> President of a Russian republic, but rejected the Bolshevik proposal that it endorse the Soviet decrees on land, peace and workers' control and acknowledge the power of the Soviets of Workers', Soldiers' and Peasants' Deputies. The next day, the Bolsheviks declared that the assembly was elected on outdated party lists<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/All-Russian_Central_Executive_Committee" title="All-Russian Central Executive Committee">All-Russian Central Executive Committee</a> of the Soviets dissolved it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup> In March 1919, world communist parties formed <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Comintern" title="Comintern">Comintern</a> (also known as the Third International) at a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Founding_Congress_of_the_Comintern" title="Founding Congress of the Comintern">meeting in Moscow</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELambDocherty200677_111-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELambDocherty200677-111">[111]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the period before World War II, Soviet Union experienced two major famines.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Neutral_point_of_view#Due_and_undue_weight" title="Wikipedia:Neutral point of view"><span title="The material near this tag may be giving undue weight to a viewpoint or idea. (September 2021)">undue weight?</span></a> <span class="metadata"> – <a href="/wiki/Talk:Socialism#undue" title="Talk:Socialism">discuss</a></span></i>]</sup> The First famine occurred in <a href="/wiki/Russian_famine_of_1921%E2%80%931922" title="Russian famine of 1921–1922">1921-1922</a> with death estimates varying between 1 and 10 million dead. It was caused by a combination of factors - severe drought and failed harvests, continuous war since 1914, forced collectivisation of farms and requisition of grain and seed from peasants (preventing the sowing of crops) by the Soviet authorities, and an economic blockade of the Soviet Union by the Allies. The experience with the famine led Lenin to replace war communism with the <a href="/wiki/New_Economic_Policy" title="New Economic Policy">New Economic Policy</a> (NEP) in 1921 to alleviate the extreme shortages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> Under the NEP, private ownership was allowed for small and medium-sized enterprises. While large industry remained state-controlled.
</p><p>A second major famine occurred in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soviet_famine_of_1932%E2%80%931933" title="Soviet famine of 1932–1933">1930-1933</a>, resulting in millions of deaths.
</p><p>The Soviet economy was the modern world's first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Centrally_planned_economy" title="Centrally planned economy">centrally planned economy</a>. It adopted state ownership of industry managed through <a href="/wiki/Gosplan" title="Gosplan">Gosplan</a> (the State Planning Commission), <a href="/wiki/Gosbank" title="Gosbank">Gosbank</a> (the State Bank) and the <a href="/wiki/Gossnab" title="Gossnab">Gossnab</a> (State Commission for Materials and Equipment Supply). Economic planning was conducted through serial <a href="/wiki/Five-year_plans_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Five-year plans of the Soviet Union">Five-Year Plans</a>. The emphasis was on development of heavy industry at expense of agriculture. Rapid industrialization served two purposes: to bring largely agrarian societies into the modern age, and to establish a politically loyal working class. Modernization brought about a general increase in the standard of living in the 1950s and 60's.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Third_International_and_the_revolutionary_wave">Third International and the revolutionary wave</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Third International and the revolutionary wave">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Communist_International" title="Communist International">Communist International</a> and <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1917%E2%80%931923" title="Revolutions of 1917–1923">Revolutions of 1917–1923</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rosa_Luxemburg.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="7618" data-file-width="5044" decoding="async" height="257" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Rosa_Luxemburg.jpg/170px-Rosa_Luxemburg.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Rosa_Luxemburg.jpg/255px-Rosa_Luxemburg.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Rosa_Luxemburg.jpg/340px-Rosa_Luxemburg.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Rosa_Luxemburg.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Rosa_Luxemburg" title="Rosa Luxemburg">Rosa Luxemburg</a>, prominent Marxist revolutionary, leader of the <a href="/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_Germany" title="Social Democratic Party of Germany">Social Democratic Party of Germany</a> and martyr and leader of the German <a href="/wiki/Spartacist_uprising" title="Spartacist uprising">Spartacist uprising</a> in 1919</div></div></div>
<p>The Bolshevik Russian Revolution of January 1918 launched <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Communist_parties" title="Communist parties">Communist parties</a> in many countries and a wave of revolutions until the mid-1920s. Few communists doubted that the Russian experience depended on successful, working-class socialist revolutions in developed capitalist countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> In 1919, Lenin and <a href="/wiki/Leon_Trotsky" title="Leon Trotsky">Leon Trotsky</a> organised the world's Communist parties into an international association of workers—the Communist International (Comintern), also called the Third International.
</p><p>The Russian Revolution influenced uprisings in other countries. The <a href="/wiki/German_Revolution_of_1918%E2%80%931919" title="German Revolution of 1918–1919">German Revolution of 1918–1919</a> replaced Germany's imperial government with a <a href="/wiki/Republic" title="Republic">republic</a>. The revolution lasted from November 1918 until the establishment of the <a href="/wiki/Weimar_Republic" title="Weimar Republic">Weimar Republic</a> in August 1919. It included an episode known as the <a href="/wiki/Bavarian_Soviet_Republic" title="Bavarian Soviet Republic">Bavarian Soviet Republic</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Spartacist_uprising" title="Spartacist uprising">Spartacist uprising</a>. A short lived <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Soviet_Republic" title="Hungarian Soviet Republic">Hungarian Soviet Republic</a> was set up in Hungary March 21 to August 1, 1919. It was led by <a href="/wiki/B%C3%A9la_Kun" title="Béla Kun">Béla Kun</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. (August 2021)">page needed</span></a></i>]</sup> It instituted a <a href="/wiki/Red_Terror" title="Red Terror">Red Terror</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. (August 2021)">page needed</span></a></i>]</sup> After the regime was put down, an even more brutal <a href="/wiki/White_Terror_(Hungary)" title="White Terror (Hungary)">White Terror</a> followed.
