Kun managed to escape to the Soviet Union, where he co-led murder of tens of thousands of White Russians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup> He was killed in the 1930 Soviet purges.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup>
</p><p>In Italy, the events known as the <i><a href="/wiki/Biennio_Rosso" title="Biennio Rosso">Biennio Rosso</a></i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dallacasa_128-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dallacasa-128">[128]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup> were characterised by mass strikes, worker demonstrations and self-management experiments through land and factory occupations. In Turin and Milan, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Workers%27_councils" title="Workers' councils">workers' councils</a> were formed and many <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Factory_occupations" title="Factory occupations">factory occupations</a> took place led by <a href="/wiki/Anarcho-syndicalism" title="Anarcho-syndicalism">anarcho-syndicalists</a> organised around the <a href="/wiki/Unione_Sindacale_Italiana" title="Unione Sindacale Italiana">Unione Sindacale Italiana</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup>
</p><p>There was a short-lived <a href="/wiki/Persian_Socialist_Soviet_Republic" title="Persian Socialist Soviet Republic">Persian Socialist Soviet Republic</a> in 1920–21. <a href="/wiki/Patagonia_Rebelde" title="Patagonia Rebelde">Patagonia Rebelde</a> was a syndicalist-led revolution in <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a> lasting for a year and a half from in 1920–21. The anarchist-led <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Guangzhou_City_Commune&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Guangzhou City Commune (page does not exist)">Guangzhou City Commune</a> in China lasted six years from 1921. In 1924, the <a href="/wiki/Mongolian_People%27s_Republic" title="Mongolian People's Republic">Mongolian People's Republic</a> was established and was ruled by the <a href="/wiki/Mongolian_People%27s_Party" title="Mongolian People's Party">Mongolian People's Party</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shinmin_Prefecture" title="Shinmin Prefecture">Shinmin Prefecture</a> in <a href="/wiki/Manchuria" title="Manchuria">Manchuria</a> lasted two years from 1929. Many of these revolutions initiated societies and economic models that have been described as socialist.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Anarchist_Library_2012_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_Anarchist_Library_2012-131">[131]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="4th_World_Congress_of_the_Communist_International">4th World Congress of the Communist International</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: 4th World Congress of the Communist International">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/4th_World_Congress_of_the_Communist_International" title="4th World Congress of the Communist International">4th World Congress of the Communist International</a></div>
<p>In 1922, the fourth congress of the <a href="/wiki/Communist_International" title="Communist International">Communist International</a> took up the policy of the <a href="/wiki/United_front" title="United front">united front</a>. It urged communists to work with rank and file social democrats while remaining critical of their leaders. They criticised those leaders for betraying the working class by supporting the capitalists' war efforts. The social democrats pointed to the dislocation caused by revolution and later the growing authoritarianism of the communist parties. The Labour Party rejected the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Great_Britain" title="Communist Party of Great Britain">Communist Party of Great Britain</a>'s application to affiliate to them in 1920.
</p><p>On seeing the Soviet State's growing coercive power in 1923, a dying Lenin said Russia had reverted to "a bourgeois tsarist machine ... barely varnished with socialism".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> After Lenin's death in January 1924, the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Communist Party of the Soviet Union">Communist Party of the Soviet Union</a>—then increasingly under the control of <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">Joseph Stalin</a>—rejected the theory that socialism could not be built solely in the Soviet Union in favour of the concept of <a href="/wiki/Socialism_in_one_country" title="Socialism in one country">socialism in one country</a>. Despite the marginalised <a href="/wiki/Left_Opposition" title="Left Opposition">Left Opposition</a>'s demand for the restoration of Soviet democracy,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Disputed_statement" title="Wikipedia:Disputed statement"><span title="This claim has reliable sources with contradicting facts (September 2021)">disputed</span></a> <span class="metadata"> – <a href="/wiki/Talk:Socialism" title="Talk:Socialism">discuss</a></span></i>]</sup> Stalin developed a bureaucratic, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Authoritarian" title="Authoritarian">authoritarian</a> government that was condemned by democratic socialists and anarchists for undermining the Revolution's ideals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Russian Revolution and its aftermath motivated national Communist parties elsewhere that gained political and social influence, in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_France" title="Communist Party of France">France</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_USA" title="Communist Party USA">United States</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_Communist_Party" title="Italian Communist Party">Italy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Chinese Communist Party">China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Communist_Party" title="Mexican Communist Party">Mexico</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Communist_Party" title="Brazilian Communist Party">Brazil</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chilean_Communist_Party" title="Chilean Communist Party">Chile</a> and <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Indonesia" title="Communist Party of Indonesia">Indonesia</a>.
</p><p>Left-wing groups which did not agree to the centralisation and abandonment of the soviets by the Bolshevik Party (see <a href="/wiki/Anti-Stalinist_left" title="Anti-Stalinist left">anti-Stalinist left</a>) led <a href="/wiki/Left-wing_uprisings_against_the_Bolsheviks" title="Left-wing uprisings against the Bolsheviks">left-wing uprisings against the Bolsheviks</a>. Such groups included <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Socialist-Revolutionary_Party" title="Socialist-Revolutionary Party">Socialist Revolutionaries</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-carr1985_135-0"><a href="#cite_note-carr1985-135">[135]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Left_Socialist_Revolutionaries" title="Left Socialist Revolutionaries">Left Socialist Revolutionaries</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mensheviks" title="Mensheviks">Mensheviks</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anarchism_in_Russia" title="Anarchism in Russia">anarchists</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-avrich1968_136-0"><a href="#cite_note-avrich1968-136">[136]</a></sup> Within this left-wing discontent, the most large-scale events were the <a href="/wiki/Kronstadt_rebellion" title="Kronstadt rebellion">Kronstadt rebellion</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Guttridge2006_137-0"><a href="#cite_note-Guttridge2006-137">[137]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Smele2006_138-0"><a href="#cite_note-Smele2006-138">[138]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Avrich1970_139-0"><a href="#cite_note-Avrich1970-139">[139]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Makhnovshchina" title="Makhnovshchina">Makhnovist movement</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-web.archive.org_140-0"><a href="#cite_note-web.archive.org-140">[140]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Second_International_and_the_Two-and-a-Half_International">The Second International and the Two-and-a-Half International</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: The Second International and the Two-and-a-Half International">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Labour_and_Socialist_International" title="Labour and Socialist International">Labour and Socialist International</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/International_Socialist_Commission" title="International Socialist Commission">International Socialist Commission</a> (ISC, also known as Berne International) was formed in February 1919 at a meeting in <a href="/wiki/Bern" title="Bern">Bern</a> by parties that wanted to resurrect the Second International.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELambDocherty200652_143-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELambDocherty200652-143">[143]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Centrist_Marxism" title="Centrist Marxism">Centrist socialist</a> parties which did not want to be a part of the resurrected Second International (ISC) or Comintern formed the <a href="/wiki/International_Working_Union_of_Socialist_Parties" title="International Working Union of Socialist Parties">International Working Union of Socialist Parties</a> (IWUSP, also known as Vienna International, Vienna Union, or Two-and-a-Half International) on 27 February 1921 at a conference in Vienna.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELambDocherty2006177_144-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELambDocherty2006177-144">[144]</a></sup> The ISC and the IWUSP joined to form the <a href="/wiki/Labour_and_Socialist_International" title="Labour and Socialist International">Labour and Socialist International</a> (LSI) in May 1923 at a meeting in <a href="/wiki/Hamburg" title="Hamburg">Hamburg</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELambDocherty2006197_145-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELambDocherty2006197-145">[145]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="From_the_Great_Depression_to_the_World_War">From the Great Depression to the World War</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: From the Great Depression to the World War">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The 1920s and 1930s were marked by an increasing divergence between democratic and reformists socialists (mainly affiliated with the Labour and Socialist International) and revolutionary socialists (mainly affiliated with the Communist International), but also by tension within the Communist movement between the dominant Stalinists and dissidents such as Trotsky's followers in the <a href="/wiki/Left_Opposition" title="Left Opposition">Left Opposition</a>. Trotsky's <a href="/wiki/Fourth_International" title="Fourth International">Fourth International</a> was established in France in 1938 when <a href="/wiki/Trotskyism" title="Trotskyism">Trotskyists</a> argued that the <a href="/wiki/Communist_International" title="Communist International">Comintern</a> or Third International had become irretrievably "lost to <a href="/wiki/Stalinism" title="Stalinism">Stalinism</a>" and thus incapable of leading the working class to power.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-transitional_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-transitional-146">[146]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Spanish_Civil_War">Spanish Civil War</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Spanish Civil War">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Civil_War" title="Spanish Civil War">Spanish Civil War</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Milicianas_CNT-FAI.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="364" data-file-width="565" decoding="async" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Milicianas_CNT-FAI.png/200px-Milicianas_CNT-FAI.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Milicianas_CNT-FAI.png/300px-Milicianas_CNT-FAI.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Milicianas_CNT-FAI.png/400px-Milicianas_CNT-FAI.png 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Milicianas_CNT-FAI.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Federaci%C3%B3n_Anarquista_Ib%C3%A9rica" title="Federación Anarquista Ibérica">FAI</a> militia during the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Revolution_of_1936" title="Spanish Revolution of 1936">Spanish Revolution</a> in 1936</div></div></div>
<p>In the Spanish Civil War (1936–1939), socialists (including the democratic socialist <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Socialist_Workers%27_Party" title="Spanish Socialist Workers' Party">Spanish Socialist Workers' Party</a> and the Marxist <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Workers%27_Party_of_Marxist_Unification" title="Workers' Party of Marxist Unification">Workers' Party of Marxist Unification</a>) participated on the <a href="/wiki/Republican_faction_(Spanish_Civil_War)" title="Republican faction (Spanish Civil War)">Republican</a> side, loyal to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Left-leaning" title="Left-leaning">left-leaning</a> <a href="/wiki/Popular_Front_(Spain)" title="Popular Front (Spain)">Popular Front</a> government of the <a href="/wiki/Second_Spanish_Republic" title="Second Spanish Republic">Second Spanish Republic</a>, in alliance with <a href="/wiki/Anarchism_in_Spain" title="Anarchism in Spain">anarchists</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Anarcho-communism" title="Anarcho-communism">communist</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anarcho-syndicalism" title="Anarcho-syndicalism">syndicalist</a> variety and supported by the socialist <a href="/wiki/Uni%C3%B3n_General_de_Trabajadores" title="Unión General de Trabajadores">Workers' General Union</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Revolution_of_1936" title="Spanish Revolution of 1936">Spanish Revolution of 1936</a> was a workers' <a href="/wiki/Social_revolution" title="Social revolution">social revolution</a> during the war, that is often seen as a model of <a href="/wiki/Socialism_from_below" title="Socialism from below">socialism from below</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Prichard_2012_p._148-0"><a href="#cite_note-Prichard_2012_p.-148">[148]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ness_2011_p._149-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ness_2011_p.-149">[149]</a></sup> An <a href="/wiki/Anarchism_in_Spain" title="Anarchism in Spain">anarchist-inspired</a> movement of peasants and workers, supported by armed militias, took control of <a href="/wiki/Barcelona" title="Barcelona">Barcelona</a> and of large areas of rural Spain where they <a href="/wiki/Collective_farming" title="Collective farming">collectivised</a> the land.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bolloten_1984,_p._54_150-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bolloten_1984,_p._54-150">[150]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Revolution_of_1936" title="Spanish Revolution of 1936">Spanish Revolution</a> was a workers' <a href="/wiki/Social_revolution" title="Social revolution">social revolution</a> that began with the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Civil_War" title="Spanish Civil War">Spanish Civil War</a> in 1936 and resulted in the widespread implementation of <a href="/wiki/Anarchism_in_Spain" title="Anarchism in Spain">anarchist</a> and more broadly <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Libertarian_socialist" title="Libertarian socialist">libertarian socialist</a> organisational principles in some areas for two to three years, primarily <a href="/wiki/Catalonia" title="Catalonia">Catalonia</a>, Aragon, <a href="/wiki/Andalusia" title="Andalusia">Andalusia</a> and parts of <a href="/wiki/Levante,_Spain" title="Levante, Spain">Levante</a>. Much of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spain%27s_economy" title="Spain's economy">Spain's economy</a> came under worker control. In anarchist strongholds like <a href="/wiki/Catalonia" title="Catalonia">Catalonia</a> the figure was as high as 75%, but lower in areas with heavy <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Spain_(main)" title="Communist Party of Spain (main)">Communist Party</a> influence, which actively resisted attempts at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Collectivisation" title="Collectivisation">collectivisation</a>. Factories were run through worker committees, <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">agrarian</a> areas became collectivised and run as <a href="/wiki/Libertarian_socialism" title="Libertarian socialism">libertarian</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commune_(intentional_community)" title="Commune (intentional community)">communes</a>. Anarchist historian <a href="/wiki/Sam_Dolgoff" title="Sam Dolgoff">Sam Dolgoff</a> estimated that about eight million people participated directly or indirectly in the Spanish Revolution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mid-20th_century">Mid-20th century</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Mid-20th century">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-World_War_II">Post-World War II</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Post-World War II">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a> and <a href="/wiki/Post-war_consensus" title="Post-war consensus">Post-war consensus</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Post%E2%80%93World_War_II_economic_expansion" title="Post–World War II economic expansion">Post–World War II economic expansion</a></div>
<p>The rise of <a href="/wiki/Nazism" title="Nazism">Nazism</a> and the start of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> led to the dissolution of the LSI in 1940. After the War, the <a href="/wiki/Socialist_International" title="Socialist International">Socialist International</a> was formed in Frankfurt in July 1951 as its successor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELambDocherty2006320_152-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELambDocherty2006320-152">[152]</a></sup>
</p><p>After World War II, social democratic governments introduced social reform and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wealth_redistribution" title="Wealth redistribution">wealth redistribution</a> via welfare and taxation. Social democratic parties dominated post-war politics in countries such as France, Italy, Czechoslovakia, Belgium and <a href="/wiki/Norway" title="Norway">Norway</a>. At one point, France claimed to be the world's most state-controlled capitalist country. It nationalised public utilities including <a href="/wiki/Charbonnages_de_France" title="Charbonnages de France">Charbonnages de France</a> (CDF), <a href="/wiki/%C3%89lectricit%C3%A9_de_France" title="Électricité de France">Électricité de France</a> (EDF), <a href="/wiki/Gaz_de_France" title="Gaz de France">Gaz de France</a> (GDF), <a href="/wiki/Air_France" title="Air France">Air France</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Banque_de_France" title="Banque de France">Banque de France</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/R%C3%A9gie_Nationale_des_Usines_Renault" title="Régie Nationale des Usines Renault">Régie Nationale des Usines Renault</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1945, the British <a href="/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK)" title="Labour Party (UK)">Labour Party</a> led by <a href="/wiki/Clement_Attlee" title="Clement Attlee">Clement Attlee</a> was elected based on a radical socialist programme. The <a href="/wiki/Attlee_ministry" title="Attlee ministry">Labour government</a> nationalised industries including mines, gas, coal, electricity, rail, iron, steel and the <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_England" title="Bank of England">Bank of England</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Petroleum" title="British Petroleum">British Petroleum</a> was officially nationalised in 1951.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Crosland" title="Anthony Crosland">Anthony Crosland</a> said that in 1956 25% of British industry was nationalised and that public employees, including those in nationalised industries, constituted a similar proportion of the country's workers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup> The Labour Governments of <a href="/wiki/Labour_government,_1964%E2%80%931970" title="Labour government, 1964–1970">1964–1970</a> and <a href="/wiki/Labour_government,_1974%E2%80%931979" title="Labour government, 1974–1979">1974–1979</a> intervened further.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup> It re-nationalised <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Steel_Corporation" title="British Steel Corporation">British Steel</a> (1967) after the Conservatives had denationalised it and nationalised <a href="/wiki/British_Leyland" title="British Leyland">British Leyland</a> (1976).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/National_Health_Service" title="National Health Service">National Health Service</a> provided taxpayer-funded health care to everyone, free at the point of service.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup> Working-class housing was provided in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Council_housing" title="Council housing">council housing</a> estates and university education became available via a school grant system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBeckett2007247_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBeckett2007247-159">[159]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Nordic_countries">Nordic countries</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Nordic countries">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Nordic_model" title="Nordic model">Nordic model</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Einar_Gerhardsen_1945.jpeg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="549" data-file-width="397" decoding="async" height="304" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Einar_Gerhardsen_1945.jpeg/220px-Einar_Gerhardsen_1945.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Einar_Gerhardsen_1945.jpeg/330px-Einar_Gerhardsen_1945.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/45/Einar_Gerhardsen_1945.jpeg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Einar_Gerhardsen_1945.jpeg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Einar_Gerhardsen" title="Einar Gerhardsen">Einar Gerhardsen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Norway" title="Prime Minister of Norway">Prime Minister of Norway</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Labour_Party_(Norway)" title="Labour Party (Norway)">Labour Party</a></div></div></div>
<p>During most of the post-war era, Sweden was governed by the <a href="/wiki/Swedish_Social_Democratic_Party" title="Swedish Social Democratic Party">Swedish Social Democratic Party</a> largely in cooperation with <a href="/wiki/Swedish_Trade_Union_Confederation" title="Swedish Trade Union Confederation">trade unions</a> and industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-svensteinmo_160-0"><a href="#cite_note-svensteinmo-160">[160]</a></sup> The party held power from 1936 to 1976, 1982 to 1991, 1994 to 2006 and since 2014, most often in minority governments. Party leader <a href="/wiki/Tage_Erlander" title="Tage Erlander">Tage Erlander</a> led the government from 1946 to 1969, the longest uninterrupted parliamentary government. These governments substantially expanded the welfare state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[161]</a></sup> Swedish Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Olof_Palme" title="Olof Palme">Olof Palme</a> identified as a "democratic socialist"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[162]</a></sup> and was described as a "revolutionary reformist".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[163]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Norwegian <a href="/wiki/Labour_Party_(Norway)" title="Labour Party (Norway)">Labour Party</a> was established in 1887 and was largely a trade union federation. The party did not proclaim a socialist agenda, elevating <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">universal suffrage</a> and dissolution of the <a href="/wiki/Union_between_Sweden_and_Norway" title="Union between Sweden and Norway">union with Sweden</a> as its top priorities. In 1899, the <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_Confederation_of_Trade_Unions" title="Norwegian Confederation of Trade Unions">Norwegian Confederation of Trade Unions</a> separated from the Labour Party. Around the time of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Revolution" title="Russian Revolution">Russian Revolution</a>, the Labour Party moved to the left and joined the <a href="/wiki/Communist_International" title="Communist International">Communist International</a> from 1919 through 1923. Thereafter, the party still regarded itself as revolutionary, but the party's left-wing broke away and established the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Norway" title="Communist Party of Norway">Communist Party of Norway</a> while the Labour Party gradually adopted a reformist line around 1930. In 1935, <a href="/wiki/Johan_Nygaardsvold" title="Johan Nygaardsvold">Johan Nygaardsvold</a> established a coalition that lasted until 1945.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SNL_164-0"><a href="#cite_note-SNL-164">[164]</a></sup>
</p><p>From 1946 to 1962, the Norwegian Labour Party held an absolute majority in the parliament led by <a href="/wiki/Einar_Gerhardsen" title="Einar Gerhardsen">Einar Gerhardsen</a>, who remained Prime Minister for seventeen years. Although the party abandoned most of its pre-war socialist ideas, the <a href="/wiki/Welfare_state" title="Welfare state">welfare state</a> was expanded under Gerhardsen to ensure the universal provision of basic human rights and stabilise the economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Esping-Andersen_165-0"><a href="#cite_note-Esping-Andersen-165">[165]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/1945_Norwegian_parliamentary_election" title="1945 Norwegian parliamentary election">1945 Norwegian parliamentary election</a>, the Communist Party took 12% of the votes, but it largely vanished during the Cold War.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[166]</a></sup> In the 1950s, <a href="/wiki/Popular_socialism" title="Popular socialism">popular socialism</a> emerged in Nordic countries. It placed itself between communism and social democracy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[167]</a></sup> In the early 1960s, the <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Left_Party_(Norway)" title="Socialist Left Party (Norway)">Socialist Left Party</a> challenged the Labour Party from the left.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SNL_164-1"><a href="#cite_note-SNL-164">[164]</a></sup> Also in the 1960s, Gerhardsen established a planning agency and tried to establish a planned economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Esping-Andersen_165-1"><a href="#cite_note-Esping-Andersen-165">[165]</a></sup> In the 1970s, a more radical socialist party, the <a href="/wiki/Workers%27_Communist_Party_(Norway)" title="Workers' Communist Party (Norway)">Worker's Communist Party</a> (AKP), broke from the Socialist Left Party and had notable influence in student associations and some trade unions. The AKP identified with <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="History of the People's Republic of China">Communist China</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Communist_Albania" title="Communist Albania">Albania</a> rather than the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Minister_Van_der_Stoel_(PvdA,_rechts,_Buitenlandse_Zaken)_met_Olof_Palme_(links),_Bestanddeelnr_931-8203_(cropped)_(2).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1050" data-file-width="760" decoding="async" height="304" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Minister_Van_der_Stoel_%28PvdA%2C_rechts%2C_Buitenlandse_Zaken%29_met_Olof_Palme_%28links%29%2C_Bestanddeelnr_931-8203_%28cropped%29_%282%29.jpg/220px-Minister_Van_der_Stoel_%28PvdA%2C_rechts%2C_Buitenlandse_Zaken%29_met_Olof_Palme_%28links%29%2C_Bestanddeelnr_931-8203_%28cropped%29_%282%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Minister_Van_der_Stoel_%28PvdA%2C_rechts%2C_Buitenlandse_Zaken%29_met_Olof_Palme_%28links%29%2C_Bestanddeelnr_931-8203_%28cropped%29_%282%29.jpg/330px-Minister_Van_der_Stoel_%28PvdA%2C_rechts%2C_Buitenlandse_Zaken%29_met_Olof_Palme_%28links%29%2C_Bestanddeelnr_931-8203_%28cropped%29_%282%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Minister_Van_der_Stoel_%28PvdA%2C_rechts%2C_Buitenlandse_Zaken%29_met_Olof_Palme_%28links%29%2C_Bestanddeelnr_931-8203_%28cropped%29_%282%29.jpg/440px-Minister_Van_der_Stoel_%28PvdA%2C_rechts%2C_Buitenlandse_Zaken%29_met_Olof_Palme_%28links%29%2C_Bestanddeelnr_931-8203_%28cropped%29_%282%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Minister_Van_der_Stoel_(PvdA,_rechts,_Buitenlandse_Zaken)_met_Olof_Palme_(links),_Bestanddeelnr_931-8203_(cropped)_(2).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Olof_Palme" title="Olof Palme">Olof Palme</a>, <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Sweden" title="Prime Minister of Sweden">Prime Minister of Sweden</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Swedish_Social_Democratic_Party" title="Swedish Social Democratic Party">Swedish Social Democratic Party</a></div></div></div>
<p>In countries such as Sweden, the <a href="/wiki/Rehn%E2%80%93Meidner_model" title="Rehn–Meidner model">Rehn–Meidner model</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup> allowed capitalists owning productive and efficient firms to retain profits at the expense of the firms' workers, exacerbating inequality and causing workers to agitate for a share of the profits in the 1970s. At that time, women working in the state sector began to demand better wages. <a href="/wiki/Rudolf_Meidner" title="Rudolf Meidner">Rudolf Meidner</a> established a study committee that came up with a 1976 proposal to transfer excess profits into worker-controlled investment funds, with the intention that firms would create jobs and pay higher wages rather than reward company owners and managers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENewman2005_78-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENewman2005-78">[78]</a></sup> Capitalists immediately labeled this proposal as socialism and launched an unprecedented opposition—including calling off the class compromise established in the 1938 <a href="/wiki/Saltsj%C3%B6baden_Agreement" title="Saltsjöbaden Agreement">Saltsjöbaden Agreement</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup> Social democratic parties are some of the oldest such parties and operate in all Nordic countries. Countries or political systems that have long been dominated by social democratic parties are often labelled social democratic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[171]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup> Those countries fit the social democratic type of "high socialism" which is described as favouring "a high level of decommodification and a low degree of stratification".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[173]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Nordic model is a form of economic-political system common to the <a href="/wiki/Nordic_countries" title="Nordic countries">Nordic countries</a> (<a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Denmark</a>, <a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">Finland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">Iceland</a>, Norway and Sweden). It has three main ingredients, namely peaceful, institutionalised negotiation between employers and trade unions; active, predictable and measured <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Macroeconomic" title="Macroeconomic">macroeconomic</a> policy; and universal welfare and free education. The welfare system is governmental in Norway and Sweden whereas trade unions play a greater role in Denmark, Finland and Iceland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fafo_174-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fafo-174">[174]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brandal_175-0"><a href="#cite_note-Brandal-175">[175]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Moene_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-Moene-176">[176]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Byrkjeflot_177-0"><a href="#cite_note-Byrkjeflot-177">[177]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup> The Nordic model is often labelled social democratic and contrasted with the conservative continental model and the liberal Anglo-American model. Major reforms in the Nordic countries are the results of consensus and compromise across the political spectrum. Key reforms were implemented under social democratic cabinets in Denmark, Norway and Sweden while centre-right parties dominated during the implementation of the model in Finland and Iceland. Since World War II, Nordic countries have largely maintained a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Social_democratic_mixed_economy" title="Social democratic mixed economy">social democratic mixed economy</a>, characterised by labour force participation, gender equality, egalitarian and universal benefits, redistribution of wealth and expansionary fiscal policy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Esping-Andersen_165-2"><a href="#cite_note-Esping-Andersen-165">[165]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fafo_174-1"><a href="#cite_note-Fafo-174">[174]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup> In 2015, then-<a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Denmark" title="Prime Minister of Denmark">Prime Minister of Denmark</a> <a href="/wiki/Lars_L%C3%B8kke_Rasmussen" title="Lars Løkke Rasmussen">Lars Løkke Rasmussen</a> denied that Denmark is socialist, saying "I know that some people in the US associate the Nordic model with some sort of socialism. Therefore I would like to make one thing clear. Denmark is far from a socialist planned economy. Denmark is a market economy".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup>
</p><p>In Norway, the first mandatory social insurances were introduced by conservative cabinets in 1895 (<a href="/wiki/Francis_Hagerup" title="Francis Hagerup">Francis Hagerups</a>'s cabinet) and 1911 (<a href="/wiki/Konow%27s_Cabinet" title="Konow's Cabinet">Konow's Cabinet</a>). During the 1930s, the Labour Party adopted the conservatives' welfare state project. After World War II, all political parties agreed that the welfare state should be expanded. Universal social security (<span title="Bokmål-language text"><i lang="nb">Folketrygden</i></span>) was introduced by the conservative <a href="/wiki/Borten%27s_Cabinet" title="Borten's Cabinet">Borten's Cabinet</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup> Norway's economy is open to the international or European market for most products and services, joining the European Union's internal market in 1994 through <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Area" title="European Economic Area">European Economic Area</a>. Some of the mixed economy institutions from the post-war period were relaxed by the conservative cabinet of the 1980s and the finance market was deregulated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup> Within the <i><a href="/wiki/Varieties_of_Capitalism" title="Varieties of Capitalism">Varieties of Capitalism</a></i>-framework, Finland, Norway and Sweden are identified as coordinated market economies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[184]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Soviet_Union_and_Eastern_Europe">Soviet Union and Eastern Europe</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Soviet Union and Eastern Europe">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="History of the Soviet Union">History of the Soviet Union</a></div>
<p>The Soviet era saw competition between the Soviet-led <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bloc" title="Eastern Bloc">Eastern Bloc</a> and the United States-led <a href="/wiki/Western_Bloc" title="Western Bloc">Western Bloc</a>. The Soviet system was seen as a rival of and a threat to Western capitalism for most of the 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[185]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. (September 2021)">page needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>The Eastern Bloc was the group of <a href="/wiki/Communist_state" title="Communist state">Communist states</a> of <a href="/wiki/Central_and_Eastern_Europe" title="Central and Eastern Europe">Central and Eastern Europe</a>, including the Soviet Union and the countries of the <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Pact" title="Warsaw Pact">Warsaw Pact</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-houghlin_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-houghlin-186">[186]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[187]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup> including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_Poland" title="People's Republic of Poland">Poland</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/German_Democratic_Republic" title="German Democratic Republic">German Democratic Republic</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_Hungary" title="People's Republic of Hungary">Hungary</a>, <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_Bulgaria" title="People's Republic of Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Czechoslovak_Socialist_Republic" title="Czechoslovak Socialist Republic">Czechoslovakia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Republic_of_Romania" title="Socialist Republic of Romania">Romania</a>, <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Socialist_Republic_of_Albania" title="People's Socialist Republic of Albania">Albania</a>, and initially <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia" title="Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a>. In the <a href="/wiki/Informbiro_period" title="Informbiro period">Informbiro period</a> from 1948, Yugoslavia under <a href="/wiki/Josip_Broz_Tito" title="Josip Broz Tito">Josip Broz Tito</a> pursued a different, more decentralised form of state socialism than the rest of the Eastern Bloc, known as <a href="/wiki/Socialist_self-management" title="Socialist self-management">Socialist self-management</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Revolution_of_1956" title="Hungarian Revolution of 1956">Hungarian Revolution of 1956</a>, a spontaneous nationwide <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Revolt" title="Revolt">revolt</a> against the Communist government brutally suppressed by Soviet forces, and USSR leader <a href="/wiki/On_the_Cult_of_Personality_and_Its_Consequences" title="On the Cult of Personality and Its Consequences">Nikita Khrushchev's denunciation of the excesses of Stalin's regime</a> during the <a href="/wiki/20th_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="20th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union">Twentieth Communist Party Congress</a> the same year<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[189]</a></sup> produced disunity within Western European Communist parties,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[190]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[191]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[192]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[193]</a></sup> leading to the emergence of the <a href="/wiki/New_Left" title="New Left">New Left</a> (see below). Over a decade later, Czechoslovakia under <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Dub%C4%8Dek" title="Alexander Dubček">Alexander Dubček</a> also attempted to pursue a more democratic model of state socialism, under the name "<a href="/wiki/Socialism_with_a_human_face" title="Socialism with a human face">Socialism with a human face</a>", during the <a href="/wiki/Prague_Spring" title="Prague Spring">Prague Spring</a>; this was also brutally suppressed by the Soviet Union.
</p>
<h4><span id="Asia.2C_Africa.2C_and_Latin_America"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Asia,_Africa,_and_Latin_America">Asia, Africa, and Latin America</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Asia, Africa, and Latin America">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Revolution" title="Chinese Communist Revolution">Chinese Communist Revolution</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cuban_Revolution" title="Cuban Revolution">Cuban Revolution</a>, <a href="/wiki/Decolonization" title="Decolonization">Decolonization</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Third_World_socialism" title="Third World socialism">Third World socialism</a></div>
<p>In the post-war years, socialism became increasingly influential in many then-developing countries. Embracing Third World socialism, countries in Africa, Asia and Latin America often nationalised industries. During India's <a href="/wiki/Indian_independence_movement" title="Indian independence movement">freedom movement</a> and fight for independence, many figures in the left-wing faction of the <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Congress" title="Indian National Congress">Indian National Congress</a> organised themselves as the <a href="/wiki/Congress_Socialist_Party" title="Congress Socialist Party">Congress Socialist Party</a>. Their politics and those of the early and intermediate periods of <a href="/wiki/Jayaprakash_Narayan" title="Jayaprakash Narayan">Jayaprakash Narayan</a>'s career combined a commitment to the socialist transformation of society with a principled opposition to the one-party authoritarianism they perceived in the Stalinist model.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Chinese Communist Revolution was the second stage in the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War" title="Chinese Civil War">Chinese Civil War</a>, which ended with the establishment of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="People's Republic of China">People's Republic of China</a> led by the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Chinese Communist Party">Chinese Communist Party</a>. The then-Chinese <a href="/wiki/Kuomintang" title="Kuomintang">Kuomintang</a> Party in the 1920s incorporated <a href="/wiki/Socialist_ideology_of_the_Kuomintang" title="Socialist ideology of the Kuomintang">Chinese socialism</a> as part of its ideology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup> Between 1958 and 1962 during the <a href="/wiki/Great_Leap_Forward" title="Great Leap Forward">Great Leap Forward</a> in the People's Republic of China, some 30 million people starved to death<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup> and at least 45 million died overall.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dikotterxii_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-dikotterxii-198">[198]</a></sup>
</p><p>The emergence of this new political entity in the frame of the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a> was complex and painful. Several tentative efforts were made to organise newly independent states in order to establish a common front to limit the United States' and the Soviet Union's influence on them. This led to the <a href="/wiki/Sino-Soviet_split" title="Sino-Soviet split">Sino-Soviet split</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a> gathered around the figures of <a href="/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru" title="Jawaharlal Nehru">Jawaharlal Nehru</a> of India, <a href="/wiki/Sukarno" title="Sukarno">Sukarno</a> of Indonesia, <a href="/wiki/Josip_Broz_Tito" title="Josip Broz Tito">Josip Broz Tito</a> of <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia" title="Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gamal_Abdel_Nasser" title="Gamal Abdel Nasser">Gamal Abdel Nasser</a> of <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a>. After the 1954 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Geneva_Conference_(1954)" title="Geneva Conference (1954)">Geneva Conference</a> which ended the <a href="/wiki/First_Indochina_War" title="First Indochina War">French war in Vietnam</a>, the 1955 <a href="/wiki/Bandung_Conference" title="Bandung Conference">Bandung Conference</a> gathered Nasser, Nehru, Tito, <a href="/wiki/Sukarno" title="Sukarno">Sukarno</a> and <a href="/wiki/Premier_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Premier of the People's Republic of China">Chinese Premier</a> <a href="/wiki/Zhou_Enlai" title="Zhou Enlai">Zhou Enlai</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[199]</a></sup> As many African countries gained independence during the 1960s, some of them rejected capitalism in favour of <a href="/wiki/African_socialism" title="African socialism">African socialism</a> as defined by <a href="/wiki/Julius_Nyerere" title="Julius Nyerere">Julius Nyerere</a> of <a href="/wiki/Tanzania" title="Tanzania">Tanzania</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/L%C3%A9opold_Senghor" title="Léopold Senghor">Léopold Senghor</a> of <a href="/wiki/Senegal" title="Senegal">Senegal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kwame_Nkrumah" title="Kwame Nkrumah">Kwame Nkrumah</a> of <a href="/wiki/Ghana" title="Ghana">Ghana</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S%C3%A9kou_Tour%C3%A9" title="Sékou Touré">Sékou Touré</a> of <a href="/wiki/Guinea" title="Guinea">Guinea</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[200]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Cuban Revolution (1953–1959) was an armed revolt conducted by <a href="/wiki/Fidel_Castro" title="Fidel Castro">Fidel Castro</a>'s <a href="/wiki/26th_of_July_Movement" title="26th of July Movement">26th of July Movement</a> and its allies against the government of <a href="/wiki/Fulgencio_Batista" title="Fulgencio Batista">Fulgencio Batista</a>. Castro's government eventually adopted communism, becoming the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Cuba" title="Communist Party of Cuba">Communist Party of Cuba</a> in October 1965.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (October 2021)">better source needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>In Indonesia in the mid-1960s, a <a href="/wiki/30_September_Movement" title="30 September Movement">coup attempt</a> blamed on the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Indonesia" title="Communist Party of Indonesia">Communist Party of Indonesia</a> (PKI) was countered by an <a href="/wiki/Indonesian_mass_killings_of_1965%E2%80%9366" title="Indonesian mass killings of 1965–66">anti-communist purge</a> led by <a href="/wiki/Suharto" title="Suharto">Suharto</a>, which mainly targeted the growing influence of the PKI and other leftist groups, with significant <a href="/wiki/CIA_activities_in_Indonesia#Anti-communist_purge" title="CIA activities in Indonesia">support from the United States</a>, which culminated in the <a href="/wiki/Transition_to_the_New_Order" title="Transition to the New Order">overthrow of Sukarno</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bevins2020_203-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bevins2020-203">[203]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[204]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[205]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup> These events resulted not only in the total destruction of the PKI but also the political left in Indonesia, and paved the way for a major shift in the balance of power in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a> towards the West, a significant turning point in the global <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[207]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[208]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="New_Left">New Left</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: New Left">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/New_Left" title="New Left">New Left</a></div>
<p>The New Left was a term used mainly in the United Kingdom and United States in reference to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Social_activism" title="Social activism">activists</a>, educators and others in the 1960s and 1970s who sought to implement a broad range of reforms on issues such as gay rights, abortion, gender roles and drugs<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Carmines_and_Layman_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-Carmines_and_Layman-210">[210]</a></sup> in contrast to earlier leftist or Marxist movements that had taken a more <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vanguardist" title="Vanguardist">vanguardist</a> approach to social justice and focused mostly on <a href="/wiki/Trade_union" title="Trade union">labour unionisation</a> and questions of social class.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[211]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[212]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[213]</a></sup> The New Left rejected involvement with the <a href="/wiki/Labour_movement" title="Labour movement">labour movement</a> and <a href="/wiki/Marxism" title="Marxism">Marxism</a>'s historical theory of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Class_struggle" title="Class struggle">class struggle</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[214]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the United States, the New Left was associated with the <a href="/wiki/Hippie" title="Hippie">Hippie movement</a> and <a href="/wiki/Opposition_to_United_States_involvement_in_the_Vietnam_War" title="Opposition to United States involvement in the Vietnam War">anti-war</a> <a href="/wiki/Student_activism" title="Student activism">college campus protest movements</a> as well as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Black_Power" title="Black Power">black liberation</a> movements such as the <a href="/wiki/Black_Panther_Party" title="Black Panther Party">Black Panther Party</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pearson_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pearson-215">[215]</a></sup> While initially formed in opposition to the "Old Left" Democratic Party, groups composing the New Left gradually became central players in the Democratic coalition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Carmines_and_Layman_210-1"><a href="#cite_note-Carmines_and_Layman-210">[210]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Protests_of_1968">Protests of 1968</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Protests of 1968">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Protests_of_1968" title="Protests of 1968">Protests of 1968</a></div>
<p>The protests of 1968 represented a worldwide escalation of social conflicts, predominantly characterised by popular rebellions against military, capitalist and bureaucratic elites who responded with an escalation of <a href="/wiki/Political_repression" title="Political repression">political repression</a>. These protests marked a turning point for the <a href="/wiki/Civil_rights_movement" title="Civil rights movement">civil rights movement</a> in the United States which produced revolutionary movements like the <a href="/wiki/Black_Panther_Party" title="Black Panther Party">Black Panther Party</a>. The prominent civil rights leader <a href="/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr." title="Martin Luther King Jr.">Martin Luther King Jr.</a> organised the "<a href="/wiki/Poor_People%27s_Campaign" title="Poor People's Campaign">Poor People's Campaign</a>" to address issues of economic justice,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[216]</a></sup> while personally showing sympathy with democratic socialism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[217]</a></sup> In reaction to the <a href="/wiki/Tet_Offensive" title="Tet Offensive">Tet Offensive</a>, protests also sparked a broad movement in opposition to the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam War</a> all over the United States and even into London, Paris, Berlin and Rome. In 1968, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_of_Anarchist_Federations" title="International of Anarchist Federations">International of Anarchist Federations</a> was founded during a conference held in <a href="/wiki/Carrara" title="Carrara">Carrara</a> by the three existing European federations of <a href="/wiki/Anarchist_Federation_(France)" title="Anarchist Federation (France)">France</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Anarchist_Federation" title="Italian Anarchist Federation">Italian</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Federaci%C3%B3n_Anarquista_Ib%C3%A9rica" title="Federación Anarquista Ibérica">Iberian Anarchist Federation</a> as well as the Bulgarian federation in French exile.
</p><p>Mass socialist movements grew not only in the United States, but also in most European countries. In many other capitalist countries, struggles against dictatorships, state repression and colonisation were also marked by protests in 1968, such as the <a href="/wiki/Tlatelolco_massacre" title="Tlatelolco massacre">Tlatelolco massacre</a> in Mexico City and the escalation of guerrilla warfare against the <a href="/wiki/Military_dictatorship_in_Brazil" title="Military dictatorship in Brazil">military dictatorship in Brazil</a>.
</p><p>Countries governed by Communist parties saw protests against bureaucratic and military elites too. In Eastern Europe, widespread protests escalated particularly in the <a href="/wiki/Prague_Spring" title="Prague Spring">Prague Spring</a> in Czechoslovakia. In response, Soviet Union occupied Czechoslovakia. The occupation was denounced by the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Communist_Party" title="Italian Communist Party">Italian</a> and <a href="/wiki/French_Communist_Party" title="French Communist Party">French</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OSA_218-0"><a href="#cite_note-OSA-218">[218]</a></sup> Communist parties and the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Finland" title="Communist Party of Finland">Communist Party of Finland</a>, but defended by the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Communist_Party" title="Portuguese Communist Party">Portuguese Communist Party</a> secretary-general <a href="/wiki/%C3%81lvaro_Cunhal" title="Álvaro Cunhal">Álvaro Cunhal</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[219]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Luxembourg" title="Communist Party of Luxembourg">Communist Party of Luxembourg</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OSA_218-1"><a href="#cite_note-OSA-218">[218]</a></sup> and conservative factions of the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Greece" title="Communist Party of Greece">Communist Party of Greece</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OSA_218-2"><a href="#cite_note-OSA-218">[218]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_Cultural_Revolution" title="Chinese Cultural Revolution">Chinese Cultural Revolution</a>, a social-political youth movement mobilised against "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bourgeois" title="Bourgeois">bourgeois</a>" elements which were seen to be infiltrating the government and society at large, aiming to restore capitalism. This movement motivated <a href="/wiki/Maoism" title="Maoism">Maoism</a>-inspired movements around the world in the context of the <a href="/wiki/Sino-Soviet_split" title="Sino-Soviet split">Sino-Soviet split</a> (see <a href="/wiki/Maoism#International_influence" title="Maoism">Maoism#International influence</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Late_20th_century">Late 20th century</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Late 20th century">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Chinese_economic_reform" title="Chinese economic reform">Chinese economic reform</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">Dissolution of the Soviet Union</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eurocommunism" title="Eurocommunism">Eurocommunism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nicaraguan_Revolution" title="Nicaraguan Revolution">Nicaraguan Revolution</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Third_Way" title="Third Way">Third Way</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Salvador_Allende_2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="440" data-file-width="400" decoding="async" height="209" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Salvador_Allende_2.jpg/190px-Salvador_Allende_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Salvador_Allende_2.jpg/285px-Salvador_Allende_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Salvador_Allende_2.jpg/380px-Salvador_Allende_2.jpg 2x" width="190"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Salvador_Allende_2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Salvador_Allende" title="Salvador Allende">Salvador Allende</a>, <a href="/wiki/President_of_Chile" title="President of Chile">President of Chile</a> and member of the <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Party_of_Chile" title="Socialist Party of Chile">Socialist Party of Chile</a>, whose presidency and life were ended by a <a href="/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Central Intelligence Agency">CIA</a>-backed <a href="/wiki/1973_Chilean_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1973 Chilean coup d'état">military coup</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[220]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>In the 1960s, a socialist tendency within the Latin American Catholic church appeared and was known as <a href="/wiki/Liberation_theology" title="Liberation theology">liberation theology</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[221]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[222]</a></sup> It motivated the Colombian priest <a href="/wiki/Camilo_Torres_Restrepo" title="Camilo Torres Restrepo">Camilo Torres Restrepo</a> to enter the <a href="/wiki/National_Liberation_Army_(Colombia)" title="National Liberation Army (Colombia)">ELN</a> guerrilla. In Chile, <a href="/wiki/Salvador_Allende" title="Salvador Allende">Salvador Allende</a>, a physician and candidate for the <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Party_of_Chile" title="Socialist Party of Chile">Socialist Party of Chile</a>, was <a href="/wiki/1970_Chilean_presidential_election" title="1970 Chilean presidential election">elected president</a> in 1970. In 1973, his government was ousted by the United States-backed military dictatorship of <a href="/wiki/Augusto_Pinochet" title="Augusto Pinochet">Augusto Pinochet</a>, which lasted until the late 1980s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[223]</a></sup> In Jamaica, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Democratic_socialist" title="Democratic socialist">democratic socialist</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[224]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Michael_Manley" title="Michael Manley">Michael Manley</a> served as the fourth <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Jamaica" title="Prime Minister of Jamaica">Prime Minister of Jamaica</a> from 1972 to 1980 and from 1989 to 1992. According to opinion polls, he remains one of Jamaica's most popular Prime Ministers since independence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[225]</a></sup> The Nicaraguan Revolution encompassed the rising opposition to the <a href="/wiki/Somoza_family" title="Somoza family">Somoza</a> dictatorship in the 1960s and 1970s, the campaign led by the <a href="/wiki/Sandinista_National_Liberation_Front" title="Sandinista National Liberation Front">Sandinista National Liberation Front</a> (FSLN) to violently oust the dictatorship in 1978–1979, the subsequent efforts of the FSLN to govern Nicaragua from 1979 until 1990<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[226]</a></sup> and the socialist measures which included wide-scale <a href="/wiki/Agrarian_reform" title="Agrarian reform">agrarian reform</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[227]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[228]</a></sup> and educational programs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[229]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Revolutionary_Government" title="People's Revolutionary Government">People's Revolutionary Government</a> was proclaimed on 13 March 1979 in <a href="/wiki/Grenada" title="Grenada">Grenada</a> which was <a href="/wiki/Grenada#United_States_and_allied_response_and_reaction" title="Grenada">overthrown by armed forces of the United States in 1983</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Salvadoran_Civil_War" title="Salvadoran Civil War">Salvadoran Civil War</a> (1979–1992) was a conflict between the military-led government of <a href="/wiki/El_Salvador" title="El Salvador">El Salvador</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Farabundo_Mart%C3%AD_National_Liberation_Front" title="Farabundo Martí National Liberation Front">Farabundo Martí National Liberation Front</a> (FMLN), a coalition or umbrella organisation of five socialist guerrilla groups. A coup on 15 October 1979 led to the killings of anti-coup protesters by the government as well as anti-disorder protesters by the guerrillas, and is widely seen as the tipping point towards the civil war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[230]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1982, the newly elected French socialist government of <a href="/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Mitterrand" title="François Mitterrand">François Mitterrand</a> nationalised parts of a few key industries, including banks and insurance companies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[231]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Eurocommunism" title="Eurocommunism">Eurocommunism</a> was a trend in the 1970s and 1980s in various Western European Communist parties to develop a theory and practice of social transformation that was more relevant for a Western European country and less aligned to the influence or control of the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Communist Party of the Soviet Union">Communist Party of the Soviet Union</a>. Outside Western Europe, it is sometimes called neocommunism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Definition_of_Eurocommunism_232-0"><a href="#cite_note-Definition_of_Eurocommunism-232">[232]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some Communist parties with strong popular support, notably the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Communist_Party" title="Italian Communist Party">Italian Communist Party</a> (PCI) and the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Spain" title="Communist Party of Spain">Communist Party of Spain</a> (PCE). adopted Eurocommunism most enthusiastically and the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Finland" title="Communist Party of Finland">Communist Party of Finland</a> was dominated by Eurocommunists. The <a href="/wiki/French_Communist_Party" title="French Communist Party">French Communist Party</a> (PCF) and many smaller parties strongly opposed Eurocommunism and stayed aligned with the Communist Party of the Soviet Union until the end of the Soviet Union. Also emerging from the Communist movement but moving in a more left-wing direction, in Italy <a href="/wiki/Autonomia_Operaia" title="Autonomia Operaia">Autonomia Operaia</a> was particularly active from 1976 to 1978; it took an important role in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Autonomist" title="Autonomist">autonomist</a> movement in the 1970s, alongside earlier organisations such as <a href="/wiki/Potere_Operaio" title="Potere Operaio">Potere Operaio</a> (created after May 1968) and <a href="/wiki/Lotta_Continua" title="Lotta Continua">Lotta Continua</a>, promoting a radical form of socialism based on working class self-activity rather than vanguard parties and state planning.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[233]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[234]</a></sup>
</p><p>Until its 1976 Geneva Congress, the Socialist International (SI) had few members outside Europe and no formal involvement with Latin America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[235]</a></sup> In the late 1970s and in the 1980s, the SI had extensive contacts and discussion with the two powers of the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>, the United States and the Soviet Union, about east–west relations and arms control, and admitted as member parties the Nicaraguan <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FSLN" title="FSLN">FSLN</a>, the left-wing <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_Independence_Party" title="Puerto Rican Independence Party">Puerto Rican Independence Party</a>, as well as former Communist parties such as the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_of_the_Left" title="Democratic Party of the Left">Democratic Party of the Left</a> of Italy and the <a href="/wiki/FRELIMO" title="FRELIMO">Front for the Liberation of Mozambique</a> (FRELIMO). The SI aided social democratic parties in re-establishing themselves when dictatorship gave way to democracy in <a href="/wiki/Carnation_Revolution" title="Carnation Revolution">Portugal (1974)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Spanish_transition_to_democracy" title="Spanish transition to democracy">Spain (1975)</a>.
</p><p>After <a href="/wiki/Mao_Zedong" title="Mao Zedong">Mao Zedong</a>'s death in 1976 and the arrest of the faction known as the <a href="/wiki/Gang_of_Four" title="Gang of Four">Gang of Four</a>, who were blamed for the excesses of the Cultural Revolution, <a href="/wiki/Deng_Xiaoping" title="Deng Xiaoping">Deng Xiaoping</a> took power and led the People's Republic of China to significant economic reforms. The <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Chinese Communist Party">Chinese Communist Party</a> (CCP) loosened governmental control over citizens' personal lives and the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_commune" title="People's commune">communes</a> were disbanded in favour of private land leases, thus China's transition from a planned economy to a mixed economy named as "<a href="/wiki/Socialism_with_Chinese_characteristics" title="Socialism with Chinese characteristics">socialism with Chinese characteristics</a>"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_e_236-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_e-236">[236]</a></sup> which maintained state ownership rights over land, state or cooperative ownership of much of the heavy industrial and manufacturing sectors and state influence in the banking and financial sectors. China adopted its current <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Constitution of the People's Republic of China">constitution</a> on 4 December 1982. <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Chinese Communist Party">Chinese Communist Party</a> <a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party">General Secretary</a> <a href="/wiki/Jiang_Zemin" title="Jiang Zemin">Jiang Zemin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Premier_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Premier of the People's Republic of China">Premiers</a> <a href="/wiki/Li_Peng" title="Li Peng">Li Peng</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zhu_Rongji" title="Zhu Rongji">Zhu Rongji</a> led the nation in the 1990s. Under their administration, China sustained an average annual <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">gross domestic product</a> growth rate of 11.2%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_i_237-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_i-237">[237]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (October 2021)">better source needed</span></a></i>]</sup> At the <a href="/wiki/6th_National_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_Vietnam" title="6th National Congress of the Communist Party of Vietnam">Sixth National Congress</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Vietnam" title="Communist Party of Vietnam">Communist Party of Vietnam</a> in December 1986, reformist politicians replaced the "old guard" government with new leadership.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stowe_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-Stowe-238">[238]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ackland_239-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ackland-239">[239]</a></sup> The reformers were led by 71-year-old <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nguyen_Van_Linh" title="Nguyen Van Linh">Nguyen Van Linh</a>, who became the party's new general secretary.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stowe_238-1"><a href="#cite_note-Stowe-238">[238]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ackland_239-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ackland-239">[239]</a></sup> Linh and the reformers implemented a series of <a href="/wiki/Free_market" title="Free market">free market</a> reforms—known as <i><span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BB%95i_M%E1%BB%9Bi" title="Đổi Mới">Đổi Mới</a></i></span></i> ("Renovation")—which carefully managed the transition from a <a href="/wiki/Planned_economy" title="Planned economy">planned economy</a> to a "<a href="/wiki/Socialist-oriented_market_economy" title="Socialist-oriented market economy">socialist-oriented market economy</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[240]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Loan_241-0"><a href="#cite_note-Loan-241">[241]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_850809_General_Secretary_of_the_CPSU_CC_M._Gorbachev_(crop).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="640" data-file-width="480" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/RIAN_archive_850809_General_Secretary_of_the_CPSU_CC_M._Gorbachev_%28crop%29.jpg/170px-RIAN_archive_850809_General_Secretary_of_the_CPSU_CC_M._Gorbachev_%28crop%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/RIAN_archive_850809_General_Secretary_of_the_CPSU_CC_M._Gorbachev_%28crop%29.jpg/255px-RIAN_archive_850809_General_Secretary_of_the_CPSU_CC_M._Gorbachev_%28crop%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/RIAN_archive_850809_General_Secretary_of_the_CPSU_CC_M._Gorbachev_%28crop%29.jpg/340px-RIAN_archive_850809_General_Secretary_of_the_CPSU_CC_M._Gorbachev_%28crop%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_850809_General_Secretary_of_the_CPSU_CC_M._Gorbachev_(crop).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev" title="Mikhail Gorbachev">Mikhail Gorbachev</a>, <a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union">General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union</a> (1985–1991)</div></div></div>
<p>The Soviet Union experienced continued increases in mortality rate (particularly among men) as far back as 1965.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rand_242-0"><a href="#cite_note-rand-242">[242]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (September 2021)">better source needed</span></a></i>]</sup> <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev" title="Mikhail Gorbachev">Mikhail Gorbachev</a> wished to move the Soviet Union towards of Nordic-style social democracy,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Accuracy_dispute#Disputed_statement" title="Wikipedia:Accuracy dispute"><span title="The material near this tag is possibly inaccurate or nonfactual. (September 2021)">dubious</span></a> <span class="metadata"> – <a href="/wiki/Talk:Socialism#Dubious" title="Talk:Socialism">discuss</a></span></i>]</sup> calling it "a socialist beacon for all mankind".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[243]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[244]</a></sup> Prior to its dissolution in 1991, the <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Economy of the Soviet Union">economy of the Soviet Union</a> was by some measures the second largest in the world after the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia1990_245-0"><a href="#cite_note-cia1990-245">[245]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-brit_246-0"><a href="#cite_note-brit-246">[246]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[247]</a></sup> This economy however was beset by economic stagnation, an inflationary spiral, shortages of consumer goods, and fiscal mismanagement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-brit_246-1"><a href="#cite_note-brit-246">[246]</a></sup> With the collapse of the Soviet Union, the economic integration of the Soviet republics was dissolved and overall industrial activity declined substantially.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[248]</a></sup>
