It combines a large state sector that comprises the commanding heights of the economy, which are guaranteed their public ownership status by law,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[352]</a></sup> with a private sector mainly engaged in commodity production and light industry responsible from anywhere between 33%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353">[353]</a></sup> to over 70% of GDP generated in 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354">[354]</a></sup> Although there has been a rapid expansion of private-sector activity since the 1980s, privatisation of state assets was virtually halted and were partially reversed in 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355"><a href="#cite_note-355">[355]</a></sup> The current Chinese economy consists of 150 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Corporatised" title="Corporatised">corporatised</a> state-owned enterprises that report directly to China's central government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[356]</a></sup> By 2008, these state-owned corporations had become increasingly dynamic and generated large increases in revenue for the state,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[357]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[358]</a></sup> resulting in a state-sector led recovery during the 2009 financial crises while accounting for most of China's economic growth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[359]</a></sup> The Chinese economic model is widely cited as a contemporary form of state capitalism, the major difference between Western capitalism and the Chinese model being the degree of state-ownership of shares in publicly listed corporations. The Socialist Republic of Vietnam has adopted a similar model after the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_Moi" title="Doi Moi">Doi Moi</a> economic renovation but slightly differs from the Chinese model in that the Vietnamese government retains firm control over the state sector and strategic industries, but allows for private-sector activity in commodity production.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[360]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: Politics">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Labour_movement" title="Labour movement">Labour movement</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_labor_problem" title="The labor problem">The labor problem</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Trade_union" title="Trade union">Trade union</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Socialists_in_Union_Square,_N.Y.C..jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4260" data-file-width="5779" decoding="async" height="192" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Socialists_in_Union_Square%2C_N.Y.C..jpg/260px-Socialists_in_Union_Square%2C_N.Y.C..jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Socialists_in_Union_Square%2C_N.Y.C..jpg/390px-Socialists_in_Union_Square%2C_N.Y.C..jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Socialists_in_Union_Square%2C_N.Y.C..jpg/520px-Socialists_in_Union_Square%2C_N.Y.C..jpg 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Socialists_in_Union_Square,_N.Y.C..jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Socialists in <a href="/wiki/Union_Square,_Manhattan" title="Union Square, Manhattan">Union Square</a>, New York City on <a href="/wiki/International_Workers%27_Day" title="International Workers' Day">May Day</a> 1912</div></div></div>
<p>While major socialist political movements include anarchism, communism, the labour movement, Marxism, social democracy, and syndicalism, independent socialist theorists, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Utopian_socialist" title="Utopian socialist">utopian socialist</a> authors, and academic supporters of socialism may not be represented in these movements. Some political groups have called themselves <i>socialist</i> while holding views that some consider antithetical to socialism. <i>Socialist</i> has been used by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Political_right" title="Political right">political right</a> as an epithet, including against individuals who do not consider themselves to be socialists and against policies that are not considered socialist by their proponents. While there are many variations of socialism, and there is no single definition encapsulating all of socialism, there have been common elements identified by scholars.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELambDocherty20061–3_361-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELambDocherty20061–3-361">[361]</a></sup>
</p><p>In his <i>Dictionary of Socialism</i> (1924), Angelo S. Rappoport analysed forty definitions of socialism to conclude that common elements of socialism include general criticism of the social effects of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Private_ownership" title="Private ownership">private ownership</a> and control of capital—as being the cause of poverty, low wages, unemployment, economic and social inequality and a lack of economic security; a general view that the solution to these problems is a form of collective control over the <a href="/wiki/Means_of_production" title="Means of production">means of production</a>, <a href="/wiki/Distribution_(economics)" title="Distribution (economics)">distribution</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Means_of_exchange" title="Means of exchange">exchange</a> (the degree and means of control vary amongst socialist movements); an agreement that the outcome of this collective control should be a society based upon <a href="/wiki/Social_justice" title="Social justice">social justice</a>, including social equality, economic protection of people and should provide a more satisfying life for most people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELambDocherty20061–2_362-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELambDocherty20061–2-362">[362]</a></sup>
</p><p>In <i>The Concepts of Socialism</i> (1975), <a href="/wiki/Bhikhu_Parekh" title="Bhikhu Parekh">Bhikhu Parekh</a> identifies four core principles of socialism and particularly socialist society, namely sociality, social responsibility, cooperation and planning.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELambDocherty20062_363-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELambDocherty20062-363">[363]</a></sup> In his study <i>Ideologies and Political Theory</i> (1996), <a href="/wiki/Michael_Freeden" title="Michael Freeden">Michael Freeden</a> states that all socialists share five themes: the first is that socialism posits that society is more than a mere collection of individuals; second, that it considers human welfare a desirable objective; third, that it considers humans by nature to be active and productive; fourth, it holds the belief of human equality; and fifth, that history is progressive and will create positive change on the condition that humans work to achieve such change.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELambDocherty20062_363-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELambDocherty20062-363">[363]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Anarchism">Anarchism</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Anarchism">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Anarchism" title="Anarchism">Anarchism</a></div>
<p>Anarchism advocates <a href="/wiki/Stateless_society" title="Stateless society">stateless societies</a> often defined as <a href="/wiki/Self-governance" title="Self-governance">self-governed</a> voluntary institutions,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364"><a href="#cite_note-364">[364]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[365]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[366]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[367]</a></sup> but that several authors have defined as more specific institutions based on non-<a href="/wiki/Hierarchy" title="Hierarchy">hierarchical</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Free_association_(communism_and_anarchism)" title="Free association (communism and anarchism)">free associations</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iaf-ifa.org_368-0"><a href="#cite_note-iaf-ifa.org-368">[368]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[369]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[370]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[371]</a></sup> While anarchism holds the <a href="/wiki/State_(polity)" title="State (polity)">state</a> to be undesirable, unnecessary or harmful,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-definition_372-0"><a href="#cite_note-definition-372">[372]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-slevin_373-0"><a href="#cite_note-slevin-373">[373]</a></sup> it is not the central aspect.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[374]</a></sup> Anarchism entails opposing <a href="/wiki/Authority" title="Authority">authority</a> or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hierarchical_organisation" title="Hierarchical organisation">hierarchical organisation</a> in the conduct of human relations, including the state system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iaf-ifa.org_368-1"><a href="#cite_note-iaf-ifa.org-368">[368]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_375-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto-375">[375]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ward_1966_376-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ward_1966-376">[376]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brown_2002_106_377-0"><a href="#cite_note-Brown_2002_106-377">[377]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[378]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[379]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[380]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mutualism_(economic_theory)" title="Mutualism (economic theory)">Mutualists</a> support market socialism, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Collectivist_anarchist" title="Collectivist anarchist">collectivist anarchists</a> favour <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Workers_cooperative" title="Workers cooperative">workers cooperatives</a> and salaries based on the amount of time contributed to production, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anarcho-communists" title="Anarcho-communists">anarcho-communists</a> advocate a direct transition from capitalism to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Libertarian_communism" title="Libertarian communism">libertarian communism</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Gift_economy" title="Gift economy">gift economy</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anarcho-syndicalist" title="Anarcho-syndicalist">anarcho-syndicalists</a> prefer workers' <a href="/wiki/Direct_action" title="Direct action">direct action</a> and the <a href="/wiki/General_strike" title="General strike">general strike</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McKay_2008_381-0"><a href="#cite_note-McKay_2008-381">[381]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Authoritarian" title="Authoritarian">authoritarian</a>–<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Libertarian" title="Libertarian">libertarian</a> struggles and disputes within the socialist movement go back to the First International and the expulsion in 1872 of the anarchists, who went on to lead the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anti-authoritarian_International" title="Anti-authoritarian International">Anti-authoritarian International</a> and then founded their own libertarian international, the <a href="/wiki/Anarchist_St._Imier_International" title="Anarchist St. Imier International">Anarchist St. Imier International</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[382]</a></sup> In 1888, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Individualist_anarchist" title="Individualist anarchist">individualist anarchist</a> <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Tucker" title="Benjamin Tucker">Benjamin Tucker</a>, who proclaimed himself to be an anarchistic socialist and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Libertarian_socialist" title="Libertarian socialist">libertarian socialist</a> in opposition to the authoritarian <a href="/wiki/State_socialism" title="State socialism">state socialism</a> and the compulsory communism, included the full text of a "Socialistic Letter" by <a href="/wiki/Ernest_Lesigne" title="Ernest Lesigne">Ernest Lesigne</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[383]</a></sup> in his essay on "State Socialism and Anarchism". According to Lesigne, there are two types of socialism: "One is dictatorial, the other libertarian".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[384]</a></sup> Tucker's two socialisms were the authoritarian state socialism which he associated to the Marxist school and the libertarian anarchist socialism, or simply anarchism, that he advocated. Tucker noted that the fact that the authoritarian "State Socialism has overshadowed other forms of Socialism gives it no right to a monopoly of the Socialistic idea".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[385]</a></sup> According to Tucker, what those two schools of socialism had in common was the <a href="/wiki/Labor_theory_of_value" title="Labor theory of value">labor theory of value</a> and the ends, by which anarchism pursued different means.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[386]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to anarchists such as the authors of <i><a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=An_Anarchist_FAQ&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="An Anarchist FAQ (page does not exist)">An Anarchist FAQ</a></i>, anarchism is one of the many traditions of socialism. For anarchists and other anti-authoritarian socialists, socialism "can only mean a classless and anti-authoritarian (i.e. libertarian) society in which people manage their own affairs, either as individuals or as part of a group (depending on the situation). In other words, it implies self-management in all aspects of life", including at the workplace.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McKay_2008_381-1"><a href="#cite_note-McKay_2008-381">[381]</a></sup> Michael Newman includes anarchism as one of many socialist traditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENewman2005_78-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENewman2005-78">[78]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Peter_Marshall_(author)" title="Peter Marshall (author)">Peter Marshall</a> argues that "[i]n general anarchism is closer to socialism than liberalism. ... Anarchism finds itself largely in the socialist camp, but it also has outriders in liberalism. It cannot be reduced to socialism, and is best seen as a separate and distinctive doctrine."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[387]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Democratic_socialism_and_social_democracy">Democratic socialism and social democracy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: Democratic socialism and social democracy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Democratic_socialism" title="Democratic socialism">Democratic socialism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Social_democracy" title="Social democracy">Social democracy</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1062260506" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="quotebox pullquote floatright" style="width:246px; ; background-color: #c6dbf7;">
<blockquote class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style="">
<p>You can't talk about ending the slums without first saying profit must be taken out of slums. You're really tampering and getting on dangerous ground because you are messing with folk then. You are messing with captains of industry. Now this means that we are treading in difficult water, because it really means that we are saying that something is wrong with capitalism. There must be a better distribution of wealth, and maybe America must move toward a democratic socialism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[388]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[389]</a></sup>
</p>
</blockquote>
<p><cite class="left-aligned" style="">—<a href="/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr." title="Martin Luther King Jr.">Martin Luther King Jr.</a>, 1966</cite>
</p>
</div>
<p>Democratic socialism represents any socialist movement that seeks to establish an economy based on <a href="/wiki/Economic_democracy" title="Economic democracy">economic democracy</a> by and for the working class. Democratic socialism is difficult to define and groups of scholars have radically different definitions for the term. Some definitions simply refer to all forms of socialism that follow an electoral, reformist or evolutionary path to socialism rather than a revolutionary one.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390">[390]</a></sup> According to Christopher Pierson, "[i]f the contrast which 1989 highlights is not that between socialism in the East and liberal democracy in the West, the latter must be recognized to have been shaped, reformed and compromised by a century of social democratic pressure". Pierson further claims that "social democratic and socialist parties within the constitutional arena in the West have almost always been involved in a politics of compromise with existing capitalist institutions (to whatever far distant prize its eyes might from time to time have been lifted)". For Pierson, "if advocates of the death of socialism accept that social democrats belong within the socialist camp, as I think they must, then the contrast between socialism (in all its variants) and liberal democracy must collapse. For <i>actually existing</i> liberal democracy is, in substantial part, a product of socialist (social democratic) forces".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[391]</a></sup>
</p><p>Social democracy is a socialist tradition of political thought.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[392]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENewman20055_393-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENewman20055-393">[393]</a></sup> Many social democrats refer to themselves as socialists or democratic socialists and some such as <a href="/wiki/Tony_Blair" title="Tony Blair">Tony Blair</a> employ these terms interchangeably.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[394]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[395]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[396]</a></sup> Others found "clear differences" between the three terms and prefer to describe their own political beliefs by using the term <i>social democracy</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[397]</a></sup> The two main directions were to establish democratic socialism or to build first a welfare state within the capitalist system. The first variant advances democratic socialism through <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reformist" title="Reformist">reformist</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gradualist" title="Gradualist">gradualist</a> methods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBusky20008_398-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBusky20008-398">[398]</a></sup> In the second variant, social democracy is a policy regime involving a <a href="/wiki/Welfare_state" title="Welfare state">welfare state</a>, <a href="/wiki/Collective_bargaining" title="Collective bargaining">collective bargaining</a> schemes, support for publicly financed public services and a mixed economy. It is often used in this manner to refer to Western and Northern Europe during the later half of the 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[399]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Foundations_of_social_democracy,_2009_400-0"><a href="#cite_note-Foundations_of_social_democracy,_2009-400">[400]</a></sup> It was described by <a href="/wiki/Jerry_Mander" title="Jerry Mander">Jerry Mander</a> as "hybrid economics", an active collaboration of capitalist and socialist visions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[401]</a></sup> Numerous studies and surveys indicate that people tend to live happier lives in social democratic societies rather than <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neoliberal" title="Neoliberal">neoliberal</a> ones.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[402]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[403]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[404]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[405]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bernstein_Eduard_1895.jpg"><img alt="Eduard Bernstein standing next to a chair and looking rightwards. He is resting his hand on the chair." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="550" data-file-width="411" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Bernstein_Eduard_1895.jpg/170px-Bernstein_Eduard_1895.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Bernstein_Eduard_1895.jpg/255px-Bernstein_Eduard_1895.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Bernstein_Eduard_1895.jpg/340px-Bernstein_Eduard_1895.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bernstein_Eduard_1895.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Eduard_Bernstein" title="Eduard Bernstein">Eduard Bernstein</a></div></div></div>
<p>Social democrats advocate for a peaceful, evolutionary transition of the economy to socialism through <a href="/wiki/Progressivism" title="Progressivism">progressive</a> social reform.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB_406-0"><a href="#cite_note-EB-406">[406]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENewman2005[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidkN8llUabGh8CpgPA74_74]_407-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENewman2005[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidkN8llUabGh8CpgPA74_74]-407">[407]</a></sup> It asserts that the only acceptable constitutional form of government is <a href="/wiki/Representative_democracy" title="Representative democracy">representative democracy</a> under the rule of law.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMeyer201391_408-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMeyer201391-408">[408]</a></sup> It promotes extending democratic decision-making beyond political democracy to include <a href="/wiki/Economic_democracy" title="Economic democracy">economic democracy</a> to guarantee employees and other economic stakeholders sufficient rights of <a href="/wiki/Co-determination" title="Co-determination">co-determination</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMeyer201391_408-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMeyer201391-408">[408]</a></sup> It supports a <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed economy</a> that opposes inequality, poverty and oppression while rejecting both a totally unregulated <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">market economy</a> or a fully <a href="/wiki/Planned_economy" title="Planned economy">planned economy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[409]</a></sup> Common social democratic policies include universal social rights and universally accessible public services such as education, health care, workers' compensation and other services, including child care and elder care.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMeyer2013137_410-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMeyer2013137-410">[410]</a></sup> Social democracy supports the trade union labour movement and supports collective bargaining rights for workers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[411]</a></sup> Most social democratic parties are affiliated with the <a href="/wiki/Socialist_International" title="Socialist International">Socialist International</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBusky20008_398-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBusky20008-398">[398]</a></sup>
</p><p>Modern democratic socialism is a broad political movement that seeks to promote the ideals of socialism within the context of a democratic system. Some democratic socialists support social democracy as a temporary measure to reform the current system while others reject reformism in favour of more revolutionary methods. Modern social democracy emphasises a program of gradual legislative modification of capitalism in order to make it more equitable and humane while the theoretical end goal of building a socialist society is relegated to the indefinite future. According to <a href="/wiki/Sheri_Berman" title="Sheri Berman">Sheri Berman</a>, Marxism is loosely held to be valuable for its emphasis on changing the world for a more just, better future.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[412]</a></sup>
</p><p>The two movements are widely similar both in terminology and in ideology, although there are a few key differences. The major difference between social democracy and democratic socialism is the object of their politics in that contemporary social democrats support a welfare state and unemployment insurance as well as other practical, progressive reforms of capitalism and are more concerned to administrate and humanise it. On the other hand, democratic socialists seek to replace capitalism with a socialist economic system, arguing that any attempt to humanise capitalism through regulations and welfare policies would distort the market and create economic contradictions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[413]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethical_and_liberal_socialism">Ethical and liberal socialism</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=37" title="Edit section: Ethical and liberal socialism">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Ethical_socialism" title="Ethical socialism">Ethical socialism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Liberal_socialism" title="Liberal socialism">Liberal socialism</a></div>
<p>Ethical socialism appeals to socialism on ethical and moral grounds as opposed to economic, egoistic and consumeristic grounds. It emphasizes the need for a morally conscious economy based upon the principles of altruism, cooperation and social justice while opposing possessive individualism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThompson200652,_58–59_414-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThompson200652,_58–59-414">[414]</a></sup> Ethical socialism has been the official philosophy of mainstream socialist parties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOrlow2000190TanseyJackson200897_415-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOrlow2000190TanseyJackson200897-415">[415]</a></sup>
</p><p>Liberal socialism incorporates liberal principles to socialism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGausKukathas2004420_416-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGausKukathas2004420-416">[416]</a></sup> It has been compared to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Social_democratic_mixed_economy" title="Social democratic mixed economy">post-war social democracy</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Adams1998_417-0"><a href="#cite_note-Adams1998-417">[417]</a></sup> for its support of a <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed economy</a> that includes both public and private capital goods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[418]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[419]</a></sup> While <a href="/wiki/Democratic_socialism" title="Democratic socialism">democratic socialism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Social_democracy" title="Social democracy">social democracy</a> are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anti-capitalist" title="Anti-capitalist">anti-capitalist</a> positions insofar as <a href="/wiki/Criticism_of_capitalism" title="Criticism of capitalism">criticism of capitalism</a> is linked to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Private_ownership" title="Private ownership">private ownership</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Means_of_production" title="Means of production">means of production</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELambDocherty20061–2_362-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELambDocherty20061–2-362">[362]</a></sup> liberal socialism identifies artificial and legalistic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Monopolies" title="Monopolies">monopolies</a> to be the fault of <a href="/wiki/Capitalism" title="Capitalism">capitalism</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[420]</a></sup> and opposes an entirely unregulated <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">market economy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ref72_421-0"><a href="#cite_note-ref72-421">[421]</a></sup> It considers both <a href="/wiki/Liberty" title="Liberty">liberty</a> and <a href="/wiki/Social_equality" title="Social equality">social equality</a> to be compatible and mutually dependent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGausKukathas2004420_416-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGausKukathas2004420-416">[416]</a></sup>
</p><p>Principles that can be described as ethical or liberal socialist have been based upon or developed by philosophers such as <a href="/wiki/John_Stuart_Mill" title="John Stuart Mill">John Stuart Mill</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eduard_Bernstein" title="Eduard Bernstein">Eduard Bernstein</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Dewey" title="John Dewey">John Dewey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carlo_Rosselli" title="Carlo Rosselli">Carlo Rosselli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Norberto_Bobbio" title="Norberto Bobbio">Norberto Bobbio</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chantal_Mouffe" title="Chantal Mouffe">Chantal Mouffe</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[422]</a></sup> Other important liberal socialist figures include Guido Calogero, <a href="/wiki/Piero_Gobetti" title="Piero Gobetti">Piero Gobetti</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Leonard_Trelawny_Hobhouse" title="Leonard Trelawny Hobhouse">Leonard Trelawny Hobhouse</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Maynard_Keynes" title="John Maynard Keynes">John Maynard Keynes</a> and <a href="/wiki/R._H._Tawney" title="R. H. Tawney">R. H. Tawney</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ref72_421-1"><a href="#cite_note-ref72-421">[421]</a></sup> Liberal socialism has been particularly prominent in British and Italian politics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ref72_421-2"><a href="#cite_note-ref72-421">[421]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Leninism_and_precedents">Leninism and precedents</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=38" title="Edit section: Leninism and precedents">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism" title="Authoritarian socialism">Authoritarian socialism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Blanquism" title="Blanquism">Blanquism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leninism" title="Leninism">Leninism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Marxism%E2%80%93Leninism" title="Marxism–Leninism">Marxism–Leninism</a></div>
<p>Blanquism is a conception of revolution named for <a href="/wiki/Louis_Auguste_Blanqui" title="Louis Auguste Blanqui">Louis Auguste Blanqui</a>. It holds that socialist revolution should be carried out by a relatively small group of highly organised and secretive conspirators.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[423]</a></sup> Upon seizing power, the revolutionaries introduce socialism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424">[424]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rosa_Luxemburg" title="Rosa Luxemburg">Rosa Luxemburg</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eduard_Bernstein" title="Eduard Bernstein">Eduard Bernstein</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bern_425-0"><a href="#cite_note-bern-425">[425]</a></sup> criticised Lenin, stating that his conception of revolution was elitist and Blanquist.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[426]</a></sup> Marxism–Leninism combines Marx's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scientific_socialist" title="Scientific socialist">scientific socialist</a> concepts and Lenin's <a href="/wiki/Anti-imperialism" title="Anti-imperialism">anti-imperialism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Democratic_centralism" title="Democratic centralism">democratic centralism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vanguardism" title="Vanguardism">vanguardism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427">[427]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Hal_Draper" title="Hal Draper">Hal Draper</a> defined <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Socialism_from_above" title="Socialism from above">socialism from above</a> as the philosophy which employs an <a href="/wiki/Elite" title="Elite">elite</a> <a href="/wiki/Administration_(government)" title="Administration (government)">administration</a> to run the <a href="/wiki/Socialist_state" title="Socialist state">socialist state</a>. The other side of socialism is a more democratic <a href="/wiki/Socialism_from_below" title="Socialism from below">socialism from below</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Two_Souls_428-0"><a href="#cite_note-Two_Souls-428">[428]</a></sup> The idea of socialism from above is much more frequently discussed in elite circles than socialism from below—even if that is the Marxist ideal—because it is more practical.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429"><a href="#cite_note-429">[429]</a></sup> Draper viewed socialism from below as being the purer, more <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marxist" title="Marxist">Marxist</a> version of socialism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[430]</a></sup> According to Draper, <a href="/wiki/Karl_Marx" title="Karl Marx">Karl Marx</a> and <a href="/wiki/Friedrich_Engels" title="Friedrich Engels">Friedrich Engels</a> were devoutly opposed to any socialist institution that was "conducive to superstitious authoritarianism". Draper makes the argument that this division echoes the division between "reformist or revolutionary, peaceful or violent, democratic or authoritarian, etc." and further identifies six major varieties of socialism from above, among them "Philanthropism", "Elitism", "Pannism", "Communism", "Permeationism" and "Socialism-from-Outside".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[431]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Arthur Lipow, Marx and Engels were "the founders of modern revolutionary democratic socialism", described as a form of "socialism from below" that is "based on a mass working-class movement, fighting from below for the extension of democracy and human freedom". This <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Type_of_socialism" title="Type of socialism">type of socialism</a> is contrasted to that of the "authoritarian, antidemocratic creed" and "the various totalitarian collectivist ideologies which claim the title of socialism" as well as "the many varieties of 'socialism from above' which have led in the twentieth century to movements and state forms in which a despotic '<a href="/wiki/New_class" title="New class">new class</a>' rules over a statified economy in the name of socialism", a division that "runs through the history of the socialist movement". Lipow identifies <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bellamyism" title="Bellamyism">Bellamyism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Stalinism" title="Stalinism">Stalinism</a> as two prominent authoritarian socialist currents within the history of the socialist movement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432"><a href="#cite_note-432">[432]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Libertarian_socialism">Libertarian socialism</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=39" title="Edit section: Libertarian socialism">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Libertarian_socialism" title="Libertarian socialism">Libertarian socialism</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Le_libertaire_25.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="832" data-file-width="577" decoding="async" height="245" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Le_libertaire_25.png/170px-Le_libertaire_25.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Le_libertaire_25.png/255px-Le_libertaire_25.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Le_libertaire_25.png/340px-Le_libertaire_25.png 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Le_libertaire_25.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anarchist" title="Anarchist">anarchist</a> journal to use the term <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Libertarian" title="Libertarian">libertarian</a></i> was <i><a href="/wiki/Le_Libertaire" title="Le Libertaire">Le Libertaire</a>, Journal du Mouvement Social</i>, published in New York City between 1858 and 1861 by French <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Libertarian_communist" title="Libertarian communist">libertarian communist</a> <a href="/wiki/Joseph_D%C3%A9jacque" title="Joseph Déjacque">Joseph Déjacque</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-theanarchistlibrary_433-0"><a href="#cite_note-theanarchistlibrary-433">[433]</a></sup> the first recorded person to describe himself as <i>libertarian.</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dejacque_434-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dejacque-434">[434]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Libertarian socialism, sometimes called <a href="/wiki/Left-libertarianism" title="Left-libertarianism">left-libertarianism</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[435]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[436]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Social_anarchism" title="Social anarchism">social anarchism</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ostergaard_1991._p._21_437-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ostergaard_1991._p._21-437">[437]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Noam_Chomsky_2004,_p._739_438-0"><a href="#cite_note-Noam_Chomsky_2004,_p._739-438">[438]</a></sup> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Socialist_libertarianism" title="Socialist libertarianism">socialist libertarianism</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439"><a href="#cite_note-439">[439]</a></sup> is an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anti-authoritarian" title="Anti-authoritarian">anti-authoritarian</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anti-statist" title="Anti-statist">anti-statist</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Libertarian" title="Libertarian">libertarian</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[440]</a></sup> tradition within socialism that rejects centralised state ownership and control<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[441]</a></sup> including criticism of <a href="/wiki/Wage_labour" title="Wage labour">wage labour</a> relationships (<a href="/wiki/Wage_slavery" title="Wage slavery">wage slavery</a>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[442]</a></sup> as well as the state itself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_443-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-443">[443]</a></sup> It emphasises <a href="/wiki/Workers%27_self-management" title="Workers' self-management">workers' self-management</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_443-1"><a href="#cite_note-:0-443">[443]</a></sup> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Libertarian_socialist_decentralization" title="Libertarian socialist decentralization">decentralised</a> structures of political organisation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[444]</a></sup> Libertarian socialism asserts that a society based on freedom and equality can be achieved through abolishing <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Authoritarian" title="Authoritarian">authoritarian</a> institutions that control production.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[445]</a></sup> Libertarian socialists generally prefer <a href="/wiki/Direct_democracy" title="Direct democracy">direct democracy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Federalism#Federalism_as_the_anarchist_and_libertarian_socialist_mode_of_political_organization" title="Federalism">federal</a> or <a href="/wiki/Confederation" title="Confederation">confederal</a> associations such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Libertarian_municipalism" title="Libertarian municipalism">libertarian municipalism</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Citizens%27_assemblies" title="Citizens' assemblies">citizens' assemblies</a>, <a href="/wiki/Trade_union" title="Trade union">trade unions</a> and <a href="/wiki/Workers%27_council" title="Workers' council">workers' councils</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-446"><a href="#cite_note-446">[446]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447"><a href="#cite_note-447">[447]</a></sup>
</p><p>Anarcho-syndicalist <a href="/wiki/Gaston_Leval" title="Gaston Leval">Gaston Leval</a> explained: "We therefore foresee a Society in which all activities will be coordinated, a structure that has, at the same time, sufficient flexibility to permit the greatest possible autonomy for social life, or for the life of each enterprise, and enough cohesiveness to prevent all disorder. ... In a well-organised society, all of these things must be systematically accomplished by means of parallel federations, vertically united at the highest levels, constituting one vast organism in which all economic functions will be performed in solidarity with all others and that will permanently preserve the necessary cohesion".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448"><a href="#cite_note-448">[448]</a></sup> All of this is generally done within a general call for <a href="/wiki/Liberty" title="Liberty">libertarian</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449"><a href="#cite_note-449">[449]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Voluntaryism" title="Voluntaryism">voluntary</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Free_association_(communism_and_anarchism)" title="Free association (communism and anarchism)">free associations</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-450"><a href="#cite_note-450">[450]</a></sup> through the identification, criticism and practical dismantling of illegitimate authority in all aspects of human life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_375-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto-375">[375]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-451"><a href="#cite_note-451">[451]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-452"><a href="#cite_note-452">[452]</a></sup>
</p><p>As part of the larger socialist movement, it seeks to distinguish itself from Bolshevism, Leninism and Marxism–Leninism as well as social democracy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-453"><a href="#cite_note-453">[453]</a></sup> Past and present political philosophies and movements commonly described as libertarian socialist include <a href="/wiki/Anarchism" title="Anarchism">anarchism</a> (<a href="/wiki/Anarcho-communism" title="Anarcho-communism">anarcho-communism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anarcho-syndicalism" title="Anarcho-syndicalism">anarcho-syndicalism</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-454"><a href="#cite_note-454">[454]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Collectivist_anarchism" title="Collectivist anarchism">collectivist anarchism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Individualist_anarchism" title="Individualist anarchism">individualist anarchism</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-455"><a href="#cite_note-455">[455]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-456"><a href="#cite_note-456">[456]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-457"><a href="#cite_note-457">[457]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Mutualism_(economic_theory)" title="Mutualism (economic theory)">mutualism</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-458"><a href="#cite_note-458">[458]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Autonomism" title="Autonomism">autonomism</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Communalism_(Bookchin)" title="Communalism (Bookchin)">Communalism</a>, participism, <a href="/wiki/Libertarian_Marxism" title="Libertarian Marxism">libertarian Marxism</a> (<a href="/wiki/Council_communism" title="Council communism">council communism</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Luxemburgism" title="Luxemburgism">Luxemburgism</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Graham-2005_459-0"><a href="#cite_note-Graham-2005-459">[459]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Revolutionary_syndicalism" title="Revolutionary syndicalism">revolutionary syndicalism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Utopian_socialism" title="Utopian socialism">utopian socialism</a> (<a href="/wiki/Fourierism" title="Fourierism">Fourierism</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-460"><a href="#cite_note-460">[460]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religious_socialism">Religious socialism</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=40" title="Edit section: Religious socialism">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religious_socialism" title="Religious socialism">Religious socialism</a></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1097763485">.mw-parser-output .ambox{border:1px solid #a2a9b1;border-left:10px solid #36c;background-color:#fbfbfb;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output ambox-Refimprove" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div class="mbox-image-div"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg"><img alt="" data-file-height="399"
